definition: A foundational framework for network access control that combines three distinct functions: Authentication (verifying identity), Authorization (determining permitted actions), and Accounting (recording resource usage for auditing, billing, and forensic reconstruction). Defined in IETF RFC 2904 and RFC 3539; forms the basis of RADIUS, Diameter, TACACS+, and 802.1X enterprise deployments (NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5 AC-2, AC-3, AU-2).

A mandatory organizational policy that explicitly defines permitted and prohibited uses of information systems, networks, internet access, email, mobile devices, and cloud services. All users must acknowledge the policy in writing or electronically; violations may result in disciplinary action or termination (NIST SP 800-53 PM-18, ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.5.1.1, PCI DSS 12.1).

The selective restriction of access to resources based on the identity of users or systems and a predefined policy. Encompasses identification, authentication, authorization, and accountability; implemented through logical (software) and physical (guards, locks) mechanisms (NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5 family AC, ISO/IEC 27001 Annex A.8).

A data structure containing entries that specify rights or permissions of subjects (users, groups, processes, IP addresses) to objects (files, directories, network resources). The primary enforcement mechanism for discretionary access control in Windows NTFS, Linux POSIX, Cisco IOS, and most firewalls (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

A formal representation of how access decisions are made. Major models include Discretionary Access Control (DAC), Mandatory Access Control (MAC), Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC), Relationship-Based Access Control (ReBAC), and Risk-Adaptable Access Control (RAdAC) (NIST SP 800-53 AC-3).

The systematic collection of valid usernames or email addresses from public sources, breached databases, social media, or automated enumeration techniques, typically used as preparation for credential stuffing or targeted phishing campaigns (OWASP Automated Threats Handbook OAT-008).

A protective mechanism that temporarily or permanently disables an account after a configurable number of consecutive failed authentication attempts to mitigate brute-force and credential-stuffing attacks (NIST SP 800-63B Section 5.2.2).

A form of identity fraud in which an attacker gains unauthorized control over a legitimate user’s online account through credential theft, phishing, session hijacking, SIM swapping, or exploitation of weak password recovery mechanisms (FTC Consumer Sentinel 2024, FBI IC3).

An exploit mitigation that randomizes the base memory addresses of executable code, stack, heap, and libraries on each program execution, significantly increasing the difficulty of memory corruption attacks (Microsoft Security, PaX Project, NIST SP 800-189).

The symmetric block cipher established by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology in 2001 as Federal Information Processing Standard 197 after an open international competition. Operates on 128-bit blocks with key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits; the global de facto standard for confidential data protection (FIPS 197).

A prolonged and targeted cyber operation conducted by a highly capable adversary (often nation-state or state-sponsored) who establishes and maintains undetected presence in a network for months or years to exfiltrate data, conduct espionage, or prepare sabotage (NIST SP 800-39, MITRE ATT&CK Framework).

The field studying attacks that manipulate machine learning systems (data poisoning, evasion, model inversion, model stealing) and corresponding defenses. Critical for securing AI-based cybersecurity tools such as malware classifiers and anomaly detection systems (NIST IR 8269, MITRE ATLAS).

A sophisticated man-in-the-middle technique using reverse-proxy toolkits (Evilginx2, Muraena, Modlishka) to intercept authentication traffic in real time and steal credentials, session tokens, and MFA responses while remaining transparent to both victim and server (MITRE ATT&CK T1557).

A computer or network deliberately isolated from all external networks (no wired, wireless, or cellular connections) to achieve the highest level of protection for classified or critical systems. Still vulnerable to physical media (USB), supply-chain attacks, or electromagnetic side-channels (NIST SP 800-53 SC-41).

The state of reduced analyst responsiveness caused by an overwhelming volume of security alerts, most of which are false positives, leading to genuine threats being overlooked (SANS Institute, Gartner Magic Quadrant for SIEM 2024).

A security control model that explicitly permits only pre-approved entities (applications, IP addresses, email senders, file hashes) and denies everything else by default. Opposite of blocklist/blacklist (NIST SP 800-167, CIS Control 2).

Deliberate methods used to frustrate digital forensic examination, including secure deletion, encryption, timestamp modification (timestomping), log wiping, trail obfuscation, data hiding, and evidence destruction (NIST SP 800-86, SANS FOR500, SWGDE Best Practices).

The practice of preventing execution of any software unless it appears on an explicitly approved list and is cryptographically verified. One of the most effective controls against ransomware and fileless malware (NIST SP 800-167, Microsoft Defender Application Control).

Any digital object or data that holds evidentiary value in an investigation, including files, registry keys, memory dumps, network packets, browser history, mobile backups, and cloud logs (NIST SP 800-86, SWGDE Digital Evidence Guidelines).

The sum of all possible locations where an unauthorized user can attempt to enter data into or extract data from an information system, including network interfaces, input fields, APIs, removable media, and third-party dependencies (OWASP, Microsoft STRIDE model).

A structured, hierarchical representation of threats where the root node is the attacker’s ultimate objective and leaf nodes represent individual techniques or conditions required to achieve sub-goals (Bruce Schneier, 1999; widely used in threat modeling).

An access control paradigm where authorization decisions are based on attributes of the user, resource, action, and environmental/contextual conditions rather than static roles or groups (NIST SP 800-162, OASIS XACML standard).

A secure, chronological, tamper-evident record of system events sufficient to enable the reconstruction and examination of the sequence of activities surrounding or leading to a security incident (ISO/IEC 27001:2022 A.12.4.1, PCI DSS Requirement 10).
The process of verifying the claimed identity of a user, device, or process before granting access to resources (NIST SP 800-63-3 Digital Identity Guidelines).

A category defined by NIST SP 800-63-3 describing the degree of confidence in an authentication process: AAL1 (single-factor), AAL2 (multi-factor), AAL3 (multi-factor using hardware cryptographic authenticators with verifier impersonation resistance).

A category of evidence used to verify identity: something you know (password), something you have (token), something you are (biometric), or contextual factors (location, time, behavior) (NIST SP 800-63B).
The process of determining whether an authenticated entity is permitted to perform a requested action on a specific resource (NIST SP 800-53 AC-2, AC-6).
Ensuring timely and reliable access to and use of information and information systems by authorized users; one of the three pillars of the CIA triad (44 U.S.C. § 3542, ISO/IEC 27000:2018).
Any attack whose primary objective is to deny legitimate users access to systems or data (e.g., DDoS, ransomware, physical destruction) (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2).

The systematic recording of all access attempts (successful and failed) to systems, applications, and data, including user ID, timestamp, source IP, and resource accessed. Essential for forensic investigations, compliance, and anomaly detection (NIST SP 800-92, ISO/IEC 27001 A.12.4.1).

The examination of historical access behavior to establish baselines and detect anomalies such as unusual data downloads, privilege escalations, or lateral movement (used in UEBA and insider threat programs – NIST SP 800-53 AU-6, AU-12).

The full lifecycle process of creating, modifying, reviewing, enabling, disabling, and deleting user accounts while enforcing least privilege and segregation of duties (NIST SP 800-53 AC-2, ISO/IEC 27001 A.5.16–A.5.18).

Microsoft’s directory service that provides centralized identity management, authentication (via Kerberos/NTLM), and authorization through Group Policy Objects in Windows domain environments (Microsoft Docs, NIST SP 800-53 AC-2).

The use of tools that send crafted packets or queries to identify live hosts, open ports, services, and vulnerabilities on a network (e.g., Nmap, Nessus) – contrast with passive reconnaissance (NIST SP 800-115).

A layer-2 attack in which an attacker sends forged ARP replies to associate their MAC address with another host’s IP address, enabling man-in-the-middle attacks on local networks (NIST SP 800-94, MITRE ATT&CK T1557.001).
Methods designed to bypass network security controls by fragmenting, encrypting, or obfuscating malicious traffic so that IDS/IPS cannot detect it (Gartner, McAfee Labs).

Controlled simulation of real-world threat actors and their TTPs (e.g., using MITRE ATT&CK Navigator, Caldera, or Red Team frameworks) to test detection and response capabilities (MITRE Engenuity, NIST SP 800-53 CA-8).
An authenticated encryption mode combining confidentiality and integrity for constrained environments such as IoT (NIST SP 800-38C).
The most widely deployed authenticated encryption mode providing both confidentiality and integrity at high speed; required in TLS 1.3 (NIST SP 800-38D, RFC 8446).
Any technique used to breach an air-gapped system, including USB drops, supply-chain compromise, electromagnetic emanation (TEMPEST), or acoustic attacks (Stuxnet, BadUSB, NSA ANT catalog).
Techniques used by attackers to execute unapproved code despite application allowlisting, such as LOLBins, signed binary proxy execution, or DLL side-loading (MITRE ATT&CK T1218).

A security anti-pattern where permissions are granted based on the execution environment rather than explicit user intent, leading to confused-deputy problems (e.g., traditional Unix setuid) (Saltzer & Schroeder 1975).
A detection method that identifies deviations from established normal behavior baselines rather than relying on known signatures (used in ML-based IDS/UEBA) (NIST SP 800-94).
Access granted without requiring user identity disclosure; acceptable only for public resources due to lack of accountability (NIST SP 800-63B).
Cryptographic mechanisms (sequence numbers, timestamps, nonces) that prevent captured packets from being successfully retransmitted (used in IPsec, Kerberos, TLS) (RFC 4303).
The practice of protecting application programming interfaces from abuse, including authentication, rate limiting, input validation, and monitoring (OWASP API Security Top 10 2023).
A firewall that operates at OSI layer 7, inspecting and filtering traffic based on application-specific protocols and behaviors (Web Application Firewall – WAF) (OWASP, NIST SP 800-41).
Synonym for Application Allowlisting – see above (NIST SP 800-167).
Malware that employs obfuscation, encryption, or polymorphism specifically to evade antivirus detection and reverse engineering.
The deliberate alteration of digital evidence by anti-forensic tools to corrupt file signatures, timestamps, or metadata while preserving apparent functionality.
A continuously maintained catalog of all hardware, software, virtual machines, containers, cloud workloads, and data assets within an organization (CIS Control 1, NIST SP 800-53 CM-8).
The process of identifying and visualizing all possible routes an attacker could take from initial access to mission-critical assets (used in MITRE ATT&CK Navigator and BloodHound).
The specific method or pathway an attacker uses to deliver a payload or exploit a vulnerability (e.g., email attachment, drive-by download, removable media) (NIST SP 800-30).
The process by which a system or device proves its integrity and configuration to a remote verifier, typically using cryptographic measurements (TCG TPM, Intel SGX, Android SafetyNet).
A digital certificate that binds attributes (roles, clearances, group memberships) to a subject without containing a public key (RFC 5755).
A cryptographic scheme where ciphertext can only be decrypted if the user’s attributes satisfy a policy embedded in the ciphertext (used in fine-grained cloud access control) (NIST IR 8302).
Security considerations for AR platforms, including sensor data protection, overlay injection prevention, and physical-world privacy (OWASP AR/VR Security Project).
An IPsec protocol that provides connectionless integrity and data origin authentication (but not confidentiality) for IPv4/IPv6 packets (RFC 4302).
The most secure OAuth 2.0 grant type that uses a back-channel exchange to obtain tokens, preventing token leakage in browsers (RFC 6749).
DHS program and STIX/TAXII standard for machine-readable cyber threat indicator exchange between organizations and government (CISA AIS).
The property that ensures data or a message is genuine and comes from the claimed source; achieved through digital signatures, HMAC, or certificates (ISO/IEC 27000:2018, NIST SP 800-53 SC-17).

The assurance that digital evidence has not been altered and is exactly as it was when collected; maintained through chain of custody and cryptographic hashing (SWGDE Best Practices for Digital Evidence).
A vulnerability class where an attacker gains access to restricted functionality or data without proper permission checks (e.g., Insecure Direct Object Reference – IDOR) (OWASP Top 10 A01:2021).
The use of tools and scripts to continuously or periodically perform penetration testing tasks (e.g., Nuclei, ZAP, Burp Suite Intruder) (NIST SP 800-115).
Continuous, machine-driven adversary emulation using frameworks such as Caldera, Infection Monkey, or Prelude Operator to test defenses 24/7 (MITRE Engenuity).
Any cyber threat executed primarily by software agents rather than human interaction (e.g., credential stuffing bots, DDoS botnets) (OWASP Automated Threats Handbook).
A collection of IP routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators that presents a common routing policy to the Internet (RFC 1930).
An isolated location inside a cloud region (AWS, Azure, GCP) designed for high availability and fault tolerance; used in cloud architecture security.
Techniques used by malware to avoid detection by antivirus engines: packing, encryption, polymorphism, metamorphism, or living-off-the-land binaries (MITRE ATT&CK T1027).
Amazon’s service for managing users, groups, roles, and permissions in the AWS cloud; foundational for least-privilege enforcement in cloud environments.
Microsoft’s cloud-based identity and access management service (now Microsoft Entra ID); supports SSO, MFA, Conditional Access, and B2B/B2C scenarios.
Microsoft’s cloud-native SIEM and SOAR solution with built-in AI and MITRE ATT&CK mapping (Microsoft Docs).
A credential used to access protected resources in OAuth 2.0 / OpenID Connect flows; can be JWT or opaque (RFC 6749, RFC 7519).
Google Cloud feature that provides logs of when and why Google personnel accessed customer data (Google Cloud Security).
The security principle that ensures actions of an entity can be traced uniquely to that entity; achieved through logging, non-repudiation, and audit trails (ISO/IEC 27000).
Microsoft’s PKI implementation that issues and manages X.509 certificates in Windows domains; frequent target of privilege escalation attacks (SpecterOps research).
The specific behaviors and methods used by threat actors; documented in MITRE ATT&CK matrices (MITRE ATT&CK Framework).
The practice of testing AI systems (LLMs, computer vision) for safety, bias, jailbreaks, and prompt injection using structured adversarial methods (Anthropic, OpenAI, NIST AI RMF).
The process of prioritizing and enriching security alerts to reduce noise and enable faster response (used in SIEM/SOAR platforms).
Residual data in file slack, unallocated space, or RAM that can contain evidence even after deletion (SANS FOR508).
A long-lived credential used to authenticate API clients; should be rotated regularly and never exposed client-side (OWASP API Security Top 10).
PCI DSS requirement for external vulnerability scanning performed by a PCI SSC-approved company (PCI SSC ASV Program).
Using ML models to assign risk scores to users, devices, or events based on behavioral patterns (UEBA systems).
The classification of assets based on business impact if compromised; drives prioritization in risk management (NIST SP 800-30 Rev. 1).
Continuous discovery, inventory, and monitoring of all internet-facing assets (domains, IPs, cloud services) to reduce exposure (Gartner).
Additional contextual information about an authentication event (device trust, location, time) used in risk-based authentication (NIST SP 800-63C).
The practice of applying security patches and updates without user intervention; critical defense against known exploits (CIS Control 7).
The portion of CVSS scoring that measures the effect of a vulnerability on system or data availability (FIRST CVSS v3.1/v4.0).

A covert mechanism that bypasses normal authentication or encryption to allow unauthorized access to a system, application, or device. May be intentionally inserted by developers, added via supply-chain attack, or implanted by malware (NIST SP 800-53 SA-10, MITRE ATT&CK T1014).

A reconnaissance technique that connects to a remote service and reads the service banner/version string returned in order to fingerprint software for targeted exploitation (OWASP Testing Guide v4.2, Nmap).

A documented set of security and functional specifications for a system at a specific point in time that serves as the reference point for change management and continuous monitoring (NIST SP 800-128, CIS Benchmarks).
The process of establishing normal behavior profiles for users, devices, or networks to enable anomaly-based detection (NIST SP 800-137).
The use of machine learning and statistical methods to detect deviations from established patterns of user or entity behavior (UEBA – User and Entity Behavior Analytics) (Gartner).
Continuous authentication using unique patterns such as keystroke dynamics, mouse movement, gait, voice cadence, or touchscreen behavior (NIST SP 800-63B Section 5.2.3).
A cryptanalytic attack that exploits the probability of hash collisions in 2^(n/2) attempts for an n-bit hash function (NIST SP 800-57 Part 1).
Microsoft’s full-disk encryption feature using AES-CBC or AES-XTS with optional TPM integration for key protection (Microsoft Docs, NIST SP 800-111).
A symmetric encryption algorithm that transforms fixed-length blocks of plaintext into ciphertext using a secret key (e.g., AES, DES) (FIPS 197).
A distributed, immutable ledger that records transactions across many nodes using cryptographic linking of blocks (NIST IR 8202).
The discipline of tracing cryptocurrency transactions, clustering addresses, and linking on-chain activity to real-world identities using tools such as Chainalysis, Elliptic, or TRM Labs.
The defensive cybersecurity team responsible for protection, detection, and response (contrast with Red Team) (SANS).
Malware that infects the Master Boot Record (MBR) or UEFI firmware to achieve persistence and kernel-level control before the OS loads (NIST SP 800-83).
A compromised device that is part of a botnet and executes commands from a C2 server (also called zombie) (NIST SP 800-83).
A network of compromised devices (bots) controlled by a botmaster, typically used for DDoS, spam, or cryptomining (NIST SP 800-83, MITRE ATT&CK T1486).
Authentication protocols that limit the number of failed attempts or validity period to reduce brute-force risk (NIST SP 800-63B).
A trial-and-error method used to obtain credentials or cryptographic keys by systematically trying all possibilities (OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet).
A vulnerability that occurs when a program writes more data to a buffer than it can hold, potentially overwriting adjacent memory and allowing code execution (CWE-120, NIST SP 800-28).
A documented plan for maintaining or restoring critical business functions after a disruption (NIST SP 800-34 Rev. 1, ISO 22301).
A targeted scam where attackers impersonate executives or vendors to trick employees into wiring money or disclosing data (FBI IC3, NIST IR 8286).
The process of determining the criticality of business activities and the potential effects of disruption (NIST SP 800-34, ISO 22301).
A property of distributed systems that allows them to function correctly even when some nodes fail or act maliciously (used in blockchain consensus) (Lamport, Shostak, Pease 1982).
One of the first widely known Windows remote access trojans (1998) created by Cult of the Dead Cow (cDc).
An attack that reprograms USB device firmware to act as a keyboard, network card, or storage device to deliver payloads (Karsten Nohl, SRLabs 2014).
An embedded processor on server motherboards (e.g., iDRAC, iLO, IPMI) that provides out-of-band management; frequent target of supply-chain and firmware attacks.
A hardened system placed on a network perimeter to withstand attacks while providing controlled access to internal resources (NIST SP 800-41).
An adaptive password-hashing algorithm based on Blowfish that incorporates a configurable work factor (cost) to resist brute-force attacks (Niels Provos, OpenBSD 1999).
An attack that manipulates Border Gateway Protocol announcements to reroute Internet traffic through malicious infrastructure (NIST SP 800-54).
The most widely used DNS server software; frequent target of remote exploits (ISC).
Presenting fake biometric characteristics (gummy fingers, deepfake voice, 3D-printed faces) to bypass biometric authentication (NIST SP 800-76).
An attack on block cipher modes (e.g., CBC) where an attacker modifies ciphertext bits to predictably alter plaintext without knowing the key.
Security testing performed without knowledge of internals, simulating a real attacker (NIST SP 800-115).
A list of entities (IPs, domains, file hashes) explicitly denied; opposite of allowlist (NIST SP 800-83).
A set of Bluetooth vulnerabilities (2017) allowing airborne takeover of devices without pairing (Armis Labs).
The process of removing manufacturer restrictions on Android devices to allow custom ROMs; increases attack surface if not re-locked.
The individual or group that controls a botnet (also called botmaster).
Executing web code in a remote container or cloud browser to protect the endpoint from drive-by attacks (Gartner).
Server-side controls that limit authentication attempts per user/IP/time window to thwart credential stuffing.
Reading past the end of a buffer, potentially leaking sensitive data (CWE-126).
Flaws in application workflow that allow attackers to bypass intended controls (e.g., price manipulation, race conditions) (OWASP Top 10).
A policy allowing employees to use personal devices for work; requires MDM/MAM controls (NIST SP 800-124).
Intermediate code generated by compilers (Java, .NET) that can be reverse-engineered relatively easily.

A pioneering remote access trojan (RAT) for Windows systems, released in 1998 by the Cult of the Dead Cow (cDc) hacking group. It allowed remote control, file access, keystroke logging, and screen capture over UDP/TCP, demonstrating early examples of backdoor persistence and command execution. While originally intended as a proof-of-concept for Windows 95/NT security flaws, it was repurposed for malicious use and highlighted the need for endpoint protection beyond firewalls. Referenced in historical malware analyses and SANS FOR610 as an early RAT example (SANS Institute, MITRE ATT&CK T1219).

A hardware-based attack vector discovered in 2014 by Karsten Nohl and researchers at SRLabs, where USB devices (keyboards, storage drives) are reprogrammed via firmware updates to emulate malicious peripherals (e.g., HID keyboards injecting keystrokes or network adapters exfiltrating data). It exploits the inherent trust in USB devices by operating systems, bypassing antivirus and requiring physical access or supply-chain compromise. Mitigation includes USBGuard, firmware signing, and device whitelisting (NIST SP 800-147, SRLabs Whitepaper).

An independent embedded processor on server motherboards (e.g., Dell iDRAC, HPE iLO, Supermicro BMC) that provides out-of-band remote management capabilities via IPMI, including power control, monitoring, and firmware updates. BMCs are frequent targets for supply-chain attacks (e.g., SolarWinds-like) and privilege escalation due to weak default credentials and isolated networks. Security best practices include network isolation, strong authentication, and regular firmware audits (NIST SP 800-193, CIS BMC Benchmarks).

A highly hardened server positioned on the network perimeter (DMZ) to provide controlled access to internal resources, acting as a gateway for remote administration or public services. It must withstand direct attacks with minimal services, strong logging, and no direct internal connectivity. Commonly used in multi-tier architectures to limit breach scope (NIST SP 800-41 Rev. 1, Cisco Secure Design).

An adaptive password-hashing function derived from the Blowfish cipher, designed in 1999 by Niels Provos for OpenBSD. It incorporates a configurable work factor (cost parameter) that exponentially increases computation time against brute-force attacks, making it resistant to GPU-accelerated cracking. Unlike SHA-256, bcrypt is slow by design for security. Used in libraries like PHP's password_hash() and recommended for storing passwords (NIST SP 800-63B Section 5.1.1.2).

A routing attack where an adversary announces false Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) prefixes to reroute Internet traffic through malicious infrastructure, enabling eavesdropping, DDoS amplification, or censorship. Notable incidents include the 2018 Amazon route leak and 2021 Fastly hijack. Mitigation involves RPKI (Resource Public Key Infrastructure) and BGPsec (RFC 8205, NIST SP 800-54 Rev. 2).

The original and most widely deployed open-source DNS server software, developed at UC Berkeley in 1984 and maintained by ISC. It handles DNS queries for authoritative and recursive resolution but has a history of vulnerabilities (e.g., CVE-2020-8616 cache poisoning). Security requires regular patching, rate limiting, and DNSSEC implementation (ISC BIND Documentation, NIST SP 800-81 Rev. 2).

An attack that presents forged biometric traits to deceive authentication systems, such as using gummy fingerprints, high-resolution photos for facial recognition, or voice synthesis for speaker verification. Success rates vary by liveness detection (e.g., 3D depth sensing). NIST recommends multi-modal biometrics and anti-spoofing measures (NIST SP 800-76 Rev. 1).

A cryptanalytic attack on block cipher modes like CBC where an attacker flips specific bits in ciphertext to predictably alter plaintext (e.g., changing '1' to '0' in IV for malleability). It undermines integrity without key knowledge. Mitigated by authenticated encryption modes like GCM (NIST SP 800-38A).

A testing methodology where the tester has no internal knowledge of the system (source code, architecture), simulating real-world attacker conditions to identify vulnerabilities through inputs/outputs (NIST SP 800-115 Technical Guide to Information Security Testing).

A security control listing entities (IP addresses, domains, file hashes, email senders) explicitly denied access or execution. Opposite of allowlist; used in firewalls, email filters, and AV (NIST SP 800-83 Rev. 1).

A set of eight Bluetooth vulnerabilities disclosed in 2017 by Armis Labs, allowing remote code execution, information disclosure, and DoS without pairing or user interaction. Affects billions of devices; mitigated by Bluetooth 5.0+ and patching (Armis Labs Whitepaper).

The process of disabling manufacturer restrictions on device bootloaders (e.g., Android's locked bootloader) to install custom ROMs or kernels. Increases flexibility but exposes the device to malware if not re-locked with verified boot (NIST SP 800-155).

The operator or controller of a botnet, who issues commands via C2 infrastructure to coordinate DDoS, spam, or cryptomining activities. Often uses DGA or fast-flux DNS for resilience (NIST SP 800-83 Rev. 1).

A security technique that executes untrusted web content in a remote virtualized container or cloud-based browser, preventing malware from reaching the endpoint device (Gartner Magic Quadrant for Endpoint Protection Platforms).

A server-side control that enforces limits on authentication attempts per user, IP, or time window (e.g., 5 attempts per 10 minutes) to mitigate automated credential guessing attacks (OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet).
A memory vulnerability where a program reads beyond the bounds of a buffer, potentially leaking sensitive data like passwords or keys from adjacent memory (CWE-126, NIST SP 800-28).

Flaws in application workflow or state management that allow attackers to manipulate processes (e.g., race conditions for double-spending, parameter tampering for discounts) without exploiting code bugs (OWASP Testing Guide v4).

An organizational policy permitting employees to use personal devices for work access, requiring endpoint management (MDM/MAM), segmentation, and data protection policies to prevent data leakage (NIST SP 800-124 Rev. 1).

Platform-independent intermediate code generated by compilers (e.g., Java bytecode, .NET CIL) that is interpreted or JIT-compiled at runtime. Vulnerable to decompilation and tampering if not obfuscated (NIST SP 800-95).
Unintended response traffic generated during a DDoS reflection/amplification attack, where spoofed queries elicit large replies from innocent servers (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2).
A wireless attack where a malicious AP or device degrades network performance for legitimate users (e.g., deauthentication floods) (NIST SP 800-97).
A predefined set of security configurations for a system type (e.g., web server baseline) used to enforce hardening (CIS Benchmarks).
ML-based monitoring that flags deviations from learned normal patterns in user, network, or system behavior (NIST SP 800-137).
The examination of executable files without source code, using disassembly, decompilation, and static/dynamic analysis to identify malware or vulnerabilities (SANS FOR610).
Firmware-level protections like Secure Boot, TPM integration, and password locks to prevent boot-time attacks (NIST SP 800-193).
A steganography technique hiding data by splitting bits across multiple files or carriers (NIST SP 800-86).
A malicious actor who violates laws or ethics to exploit systems for personal gain, espionage, or disruption (contrast with white/gray hat) (SANS).
Algorithms defining how block ciphers process data larger than block size (e.g., ECB, CBC, GCM); ECB is insecure for confidentiality (NIST SP 800-38A).
Trusted third-party services that feed external data into smart contracts, vulnerable to manipulation if not decentralized (NIST IR 8202).
Malware targeting the Master Boot Record (MBR) or EFI partition to load before the OS, achieving persistence (NIST SP 800-83).
The communication infrastructure (HTTP, IRC, P2P) used by bot herders to issue commands to infected bots (MITRE ATT&CK T1071).
Security controls at network perimeters (firewalls, IDS/IPS) to inspect and filter inbound/outbound traffic (NIST SP 800-41).
The first known PC virus, created in 1986 by the Basit and Amjad brothers in Pakistan as a boot sector infector for floppy disks (SANS Malware Analysis).
An insider threat where attackers introduce infected USBs, Raspberry Pis, or rogue devices to the network (SANS Insider Threat).
An attack injecting malicious content into browser caches via cache-busting or timing exploits, leading to persistent XSS (OWASP).
A variant of buffer overflow where data is written before the buffer start, potentially corrupting heap metadata (CWE-786).
The redesign of workflows to incorporate security by design, reducing legacy vulnerabilities (ISO 27001 A.14.2).

Unintended response traffic generated during a DDoS reflection/amplification attack, where an attacker spoofs the victim's IP in queries to public servers (DNS, NTP, SSDP), causing those servers to flood the victim with large replies. This technique amplifies attack volume by factors of 50–500x, overwhelming bandwidth and resources. Mitigation includes ingress filtering (BCP 38), rate limiting on amplifiers, and monitoring for anomalous inbound UDP traffic (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2, MITRE ATT&CK T1498).

A wireless network attack where a malicious device or rogue access point intentionally degrades performance for legitimate users through deauthentication floods, channel jamming, or excessive beaconing, forcing disconnections or slowdowns. Common in Wi-Fi environments, it exploits 802.11 protocol weaknesses. Detection uses spectrum analyzers; prevention involves WPA3, client isolation, and rogue AP detection (NIST SP 800-97, Cisco Wireless Security).

A predefined, hardened set of security configurations tailored to a system type (e.g., web server, database, endpoint), including disabled unnecessary services, strong passwords, and patched vulnerabilities, used to enforce compliance and reduce attack surface. Regularly audited against standards like CIS Benchmarks or STIGs (NIST SP 800-128, DISA STIGs).

An AI/ML-driven security technique that establishes baselines of normal user, network, or system behavior and flags deviations (e.g., unusual login times or data exfiltration patterns) as potential threats. Used in UEBA and NDR systems to detect insider threats or zero-days. Challenges include false positives; mitigated by tuning and hybrid rules (NIST SP 800-137, Gartner UEBA Magic Quadrant).

The reverse engineering of executable binaries without source code access, involving disassembly (e.g., IDA Pro), decompilation (Ghidra), and dynamic analysis (sandboxing) to identify malware behaviors, vulnerabilities, or backdoors. Essential in incident response and malware hunting (SANS FOR610, MITRE ATT&CK T1027).

Firmware-level protections in the Basic Input/Output System (BIOS) or Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) that prevent unauthorized boot modifications, including Secure Boot (verifying signatures), TPM integration for measured boot, and password locks. Attacks like LoJax target firmware; mitigation requires updates and supply-chain verification (NIST SP 800-193, UEFI Forum).

A steganography technique that conceals data by distributing bits across multiple carrier files (e.g., embedding one bit per pixel in several images), making detection harder than single-file hiding. Forensic recovery uses statistical analysis; prevention involves file integrity monitoring (NIST SP 800-86, SANS FOR508).

A malicious actor who exploits systems for personal gain, disruption, or espionage, violating laws and ethics (contrast with white-hat ethical hackers). Often uses tools like Metasploit for unauthorized access. Prosecution under CFAA (U.S.) or Computer Misuse Act (U.K.); detection via honeypots (SANS, FBI).

Cryptographic algorithms specifying how block ciphers (e.g., AES) process data larger than block size: ECB (insecure due to patterns), CBC (chaining for diffusion but malleable), CTR (parallelizable stream-like), GCM (authenticated encryption). Selection based on use case (confidentiality vs. integrity) (NIST SP 800-38A, FIPS 197).

External data feeds (e.g., Chainlink) that provide off-chain information (prices, weather) to smart contracts on blockchain, enabling real-world interaction. Vulnerabilities include data manipulation or downtime; secured via decentralized oracles and reputation systems (NIST IR 8202).

Malware that overwrites the Master Boot Record (MBR) or EFI System Partition to load before the OS, evading AV and achieving persistence (e.g., CIH virus). Forensics recovers via bootable tools; prevention with Secure Boot and offline scans (NIST SP 800-83 Rev. 1).

The covert communication channel (HTTP, DNS, P2P) between a bot herder and infected bots for issuing commands like DDoS or exfiltration. Evasion uses domain generation algorithms (DGA); disruption via sinkholing or takedowns (MITRE ATT&CK T1071, FBI Operation Bot Fry).

Layered security controls at network perimeters (firewalls, proxies, IPS) to inspect and filter inbound/outbound traffic based on policy, preventing unauthorized access or exfiltration. Evolving to micro-segmentation in zero-trust (NIST SP 800-41 Rev. 1, CIS Control 13).

The first known IBM PC-compatible virus, created in 1986 by Pakistani brothers Basit and Amjad Farooq Alvi as a boot sector infector on floppy disks to protect their software. Spread via infected floppies; historical significance in malware evolution (SANS Malware History).

An insider threat variant where attackers introduce compromised devices (e.g., infected USBs, Raspberry Pi keystroke injectors) to bypass perimeter defenses and exfiltrate data. Mitigation includes USB restrictions and device profiling (SANS Insider Threat Program).

An attack injecting malicious content into browser caches via cache-busting techniques or timing exploits, leading to persistent client-side XSS or credential theft on revisit. Prevention: strict CSP and no-cache headers (OWASP).

A memory corruption vulnerability where data is written or read before the start of a buffer, potentially corrupting heap metadata or enabling code execution. Less common than overflows but exploitable in C/C++ (CWE-786, NIST SP 800-28).

A management strategy for redesigning workflows to incorporate security by design, eliminating legacy vulnerabilities and improving efficiency (e.g., integrating DevSecOps). Based on Hammer and Champy (1993); applied in ISO 27001 A.14.2.

The fundamental unit of digital information storage, consisting of 8 bits (binary digits, 0 or 1), capable of representing 256 values (0–255). In forensics, bytes are analyzed for patterns in slack/unallocated space (NIST IR 7298 Rev. 3).

A type of malware disguised as legitimate software that creates a hidden entry point for remote control, often via RAT capabilities (e.g., NetBus). Differs from rootkits by focusing on access rather than concealment (NIST SP 800-83).

The gradual deviation of system configurations from the approved baseline due to untracked changes, increasing vulnerability exposure. Monitored via configuration management tools like Puppet or Ansible (NIST SP 800-128).

A formal confidentiality model for multilevel security systems, enforcing 'no read up' (simple security property) and 'no write down' (*-property) to prevent unauthorized information flow in classified environments (DoD 5200.28-STD).

A formal integrity model that prevents information compromise by enforcing 'no read down' (simple integrity) and 'no write up' (*-integrity), opposite of Bell-LaPadula for confidentiality (Kenneth Biba, 1977).
Unstructured binary data stored in databases (e.g., images, videos), vulnerable to injection if not sanitized. In forensics, BLOBs are carved from unallocated space (OWASP).
Techniques to defeat biometric systems, such as spoofing with replicas or replay attacks on captured templates. Mitigated by liveness detection (NIST SP 800-76 Rev. 1).
Microsoft's portable encryption for removable media using BitLocker, protecting data on USB drives with password or TPM (Microsoft Docs).
A reactive security control denying known-bad entities (e.g., IPs in blocklists like Spamhaus). Less effective than allowlisting for zero-days (NIST SP 800-83).
An attack altering the boot process (e.g., via evil maid or firmware implants) to load malware before OS checks. Prevented by Secure Boot (NIST SP 800-193).
A router at the network edge enforcing ACLs and policies to segment trusted/untrusted zones (NIST SP 800-41).
Multi-layered defenses against exhaustive attacks, including lockouts, CAPTCHAs, and WAF rules (OWASP).
Generic CWE category for buffer-related flaws leading to overflows, underflows, or leaks (CWE-119).
Simulations (tabletop, full-scale) to validate BCP effectiveness against disruptions (NIST SP 800-34 Rev. 1).
A distributed systems puzzle modeling consensus in untrusted environments, foundational to blockchain security (Lamport et al., 1982).

A social engineering attack that uses physical media (e.g., infected USB labeled “Confidential Salary 2025”) left in public areas to exploit curiosity and trigger infection when plugged in. Same principle as road apple attacks; very effective in corporate environments (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2, SANS SEC504).
A fraudulent advertising tactic repurposed in phishing where victims are lured with legitimate-looking offers (free software, prizes) and redirected to malicious sites (FTC, OWASP).

The fragmentation of the global Internet into regional or national networks with restricted cross-border traffic due to censorship, data sovereignty laws, or geopolitical conflicts (e.g., Great Firewall of China, Russia’s Sovereign Internet Law).
Intentional degradation of network performance by flooding legitimate traffic or exploiting QoS misconfigurations to make services unusable without full DoS (ENISA Threat Landscape).
Specialized malware designed to steal online banking credentials via webinjects, form grabbing, screen capture, and transaction manipulation (e.g., Zeus, Emotet, TrickBot) (FBI IC3, Kaspersky).
A binary-to-text encoding scheme commonly misused by attackers to obfuscate payloads in phishing emails, PowerShell scripts, or C2 traffic. Not encryption (RFC 4648, MITRE ATT&CK T1027).
The systematic removal or disabling of unnecessary features, services, accounts, and ports from a system to reduce attack surface before deployment (CIS Benchmarks, DISA STIGs).
An isolated Active Directory forest used exclusively for administrative access (Microsoft Tier 0 isolation model) to prevent lateral movement from compromised workstations.
A BGP extension (RFC 5575) that distributes firewall rules across routers to block DDoS traffic at line speed near the source (used by Cloudflare, Akamai).

The shift in ransomware strategy from mass spraying to highly targeted attacks against high-value organizations willing to pay millions (e.g., Colonial Pipeline, JBS) (FBI, Coveware Quarterly Reports).
Adding junk bytes to malware to alter file hash and evade hash-based detection (MITRE ATT&CK T1027.001).
Cryptographic techniques (fuzzy extractors, secure sketches, homomorphic encryption) to store biometric data irreversibly and cancelably (ISO/IEC 24745, NIST SP 800-76).
Copying BIOS from slow ROM to faster RAM for performance; exploited in some firmware attacks to modify code in memory.
A 48-digit numerical password used to unlock BitLocker-encrypted drives when TPM fails or password is lost; must be escrowed in AD or MBAM (Microsoft).
Routing malicious traffic to a null route (drop) or sinkhole server for DDoS mitigation (RFC 3882, CISA).
Malware combining multiple attack vectors (worm + virus + trojan + spyware) for maximum spread and damage (e.g., Nimda 2001, WannaCry 2017) (SANS).
Full-disk or partition encryption at the block layer (e.g., dm-crypt/LUKS, BitLocker XTS-AES) transparent to applications (NIST SP 800-111).
Microsoft’s internal security conference opened to select external researchers for responsible disclosure.
Impersonating trusted BLE devices (e.g., Tile trackers, medical devices) to trigger actions or track victims (BlueSnarf, BlueBorne follow-ups).
Legacy malware that infects the boot sector of floppy disks or hard drives (e.g., Michelangelo, Stoned) – largely obsolete but still educational (SANS FOR500).
The initial secure channel establishment process in cryptographic protocols (e.g., TLS handshake, SSH key exchange).
A UEFI bootkit used by the Russian APT29 (Cozy Bear) to achieve persistent firmware-level access (Mandiant 2022).
Seizing control of a botnet’s domain or IP and redirecting C2 traffic to a law enforcement or researcher-controlled server to disrupt operations and gather intelligence (Microsoft DCU, FBI).
Input validation performed at trust boundaries (client-server, network zones) to prevent injection attacks (OWASP).
Continuous automated testing tools (SafeBreach, XM Cyber, AttackIQ) that simulate real attacker TTPs to validate detection and prevention controls (Gartner).
Emergency administrative account with extreme privileges, sealed and monitored, used only during disasters (also called firecall or break-the-glass) (NIST SP 800-53 AC-2).
Attack inserting malicious packets into cable/DSL networks via rogue CMTS or compromised modems (Cable Haunt).
A phishing technique creating a fake browser window inside the real browser to steal credentials (mr.d0x, Zscaler).
The total number of possible combinations in a password or key (e.g., 95^12 for 12-character complex passwords).
Disposable hardware (phone, laptop) used by attackers or red teams to avoid attribution.
Aligning security investments and controls with business risk appetite and critical processes rather than purely technical metrics (ISACA COBIT).
Unicode signature bytes (FE FF, FF FE) at file start; sometimes abused in polyglot files or evasion.
Malware feature that opens a reverse connection from victim to attacker C2, bypassing firewalls (common in RATs).
Windows vulnerability (CVE-2016-3213) allowing NTLM relay through WPAD abuse across networks (Microsoft).
A compromised or mule bank account used to receive and launder stolen funds (common in BEC).
Periodic comparison of current system state against approved baseline to detect unauthorized changes (NIST SP 800-128).
Using the same IP announcement from multiple geographic locations for DDoS mitigation and low-latency delivery (Cloudflare, Fastly).
Runtime modification of executable code for analysis or hooking (e.g., Intel PIN, Frida, DynamoRIO) used in both malware analysis and EDR evasion.
Algorithms detecting spoof attempts via liveness checks (pulse, 3D depth, thermal) (ISO/IEC 30107).
Ensuring the boot chain (firmware → bootloader → kernel → init) is untampered using Secure Boot, TPM PCRs, and remote attestation (NIST SP 800-155).
Temporary, short-lived botnet assembled for a specific attack then dismantled (opposite of persistent botnets).
Compromising legitimate or malicious extensions to steal data or redirect traffic (Great Suspender incident 2021).
Rendering a device completely inoperable via malicious firmware update or hardware attack (e.g., NotPetya on MBR).
Classic exploitation methods: stack smashing, SEH overwrite, heap spraying, ROP chains, JIT spraying.
The broader discipline encompassing business continuity, disaster recovery, crisis management, and cyber resilience (ISO 22301).
Allowing users to upload client certificates for mutual TLS authentication (common in zero-trust).
Network flow control mechanism sometimes abused in DoS attacks by slowing responses.
Hypothesized (2013) bootkit using ultrasonic communication between air-gapped machines (controversial, never confirmed).
Dynamic webinjects that display fake login or 2FA screens over legitimate banking sites (Zeus Panda, Anubis).
Any unauthorized change from the approved configuration baseline, triggering alerts (CM-6 in NIST SP 800-53).
Post-incident phase evaluating attacker success, data loss, and system impact (military term adopted in cyber).
Periodic outbound communication from compromised hosts to C2 servers, used for detection in EDR/NDR.
EDR technique that blocks processes exhibiting suspicious behavior patterns in real time (CrowdStrike, Carbon Black).
Google’s implementation of zero-trust architecture treating every access as untrusted regardless of location (Google Whitepaper 2014).
Comparing two versions of a binary to identify changes (e.g., patched vulnerabilities) using tools like BinDiff.
Leak of irreversible biometric templates (fingerprints, iris scans) that cannot be changed like passwords (2015 OPM breach, 2019 BioStar 2).
Fraudulently issued or stolen TLS certificate used to impersonate legitimate sites (DigiNotar 2011, Symantec incidents).
International law enforcement efforts (e.g., Avalanche, GameOver Zeus, Emotet) involving sinkholing, arrests, and infrastructure seizure.
Techniques (canvas defender, user-agent spoofing) to reduce tracking uniqueness (EFF Panopticlick).
Distributing password cracking across GPUs/ASICs/cloud clusters (Hashcat, John the Ripper).
Advanced BEC using vendor email compromise (VEC), conversation hijacking, or deepfake voice/video (FBI 2024).
Runtime modification of Java/.NET bytecode for evasion or exploitation (e.g., GraalVM attacks).
Unauthorized administrative account planted by attackers or insiders (SolarWinds SUNBURST created NETUSER accounts).
Using file hashes or digital signatures to verify system files match the approved baseline (Tripwire, OSSEC).
Binding cryptographic keys to biometric templates so keys are reconstructed only on successful match (IEEE 2410).
Physical attack replacing laptop boot drive during short absence (evil maid scenario).
Methods used by bot herders: pay-per-install, rental for DDoS, credential theft resale, cryptomining.
Using a compromised browser session as a launching point for lateral movement (e.g., via WebDAV or extensions).
Compiler and OS mitigations: ASLR, DEP/NX, stack canaries, Control-Flow Integrity (CFI).
Using third-party identity providers (Google, Okta) for authentication instead of local accounts (zero-trust).

One of the most prolific email worms (2004–2006) that spread via mass-mailing with its own SMTP engine, opened backdoors on port 6777, and downloaded additional malware. First major worm to use social engineering subject lines like “Re: Hello” and fake PDF attachments (SANS, Kaspersky).
VMware memory management technique abused by attackers to trigger DoS by inflating guest memory usage until host crashes (CVE-2018-6981).
One of the oldest and most respected public OSINT feeds for malicious IPs, domains, and C2 servers used by thousands of organizations in blocklists.
Techniques used by attackers to bypass IP/domain/email bans (e.g., fast-flux, snowshoe spamming, disposable accounts) (MITRE ATT&CK T1090.004).

2023 Chinese state-sponsored supply-chain attack via malicious firmware updates on Barracuda Email Security Gateway appliances, leading to full compromise and data exfiltration for months (Mandiant, Barracuda Advisory).

Advanced call-center social engineering campaign (2020–2024) by TrickBot/Conti/Ryuk group where victims receive phone calls pretending to be Microsoft support after clicking malicious Excel (CrowdStrike, Microsoft).
Business Continuity Planning and Disaster Recovery – the full lifecycle from risk assessment through testing and maintenance (ISO 22301, NIST SP 800-34 Rev. 1).
Wi-Fi DoS attack flooding fake beacon frames to overwhelm client device AP lists (used by Wifatch, rogue AP tools).
Open-source tool for hooking browsers and performing client-side attacks (XSS, keylogging, port scanning from browser) (OWASP, Kali Linux).
Next-gen endpoint protection that blocks processes in real time based on malicious behavior chains rather than signatures (CrowdStrike Falcon, SentinelOne, Carbon Black).
Foundational cryptographic model for authenticated encryption (1993–1997) that led to modern AEAD modes like GCM and ChaCha20-Poly1305.
Public BGP monitoring tools (BGPmon, Kentik, ThousandEyes) used to detect route hijacks and leaks in real time.
2023–2025 ransomware family notable for leaking data even when ransom is paid, targeting Middle East and Latin America (Palo Alto Unit 42).
Exploitation of insecure Windows search order (DLL hijacking) by placing malicious DLLs in directories searched before system32 (Microsoft, MITRE T1574.001).
Advanced UEFI bootkit framework capable of patching legitimate firmware images (ESET research on MoonBounce, 2022).
Low-level Windows graphics API hooking used by rootkits and some EDRs for screen capture or UI manipulation.
Primitive ransomware (2021) that exploited ProxyLogon Exchange zero-days within hours of disclosure (Microsoft).
RaaS group behind Colonial Pipeline attack (2021), rebranded multiple times (BlackMatter → Alphv/BlackCat) (FBI, Elliptic).
SQLi variant where no error messages are returned; attacker infers data via true/false conditions or time delays (OWASP Top 10).
Open-source Active Directory attack graph tool that maps privilege relationships using Cypher queries on Neo4j (SpecterOps, 2016).
Critical remote code execution vulnerability in Windows RDP affecting XP–7/Server 2008; wormable like WannaCry (Microsoft, NSA).
GRUB2 buffer overflow allowing bypass of Secure Boot on most Linux/BSD systems (2020) (Eclypsium).
Chinese APT41 DDoS tool that uses compromised SOHO routers as amplifiers (NSFOCUS, 2021).
One of the largest botnets ever (2008–present), infected 10–15 million hosts using Windows MS08-067 and brute-force (still active in 2025).
Web-based administration interface used by cybercriminals to manage infected machines (e.g., Andromeda panel, Zeus panel).
Cryptographic model where keys remain secure even if bounded side-channel leakage occurs (e.g., DPA-resistant implementations).
Advanced credential phishing framework combining email, SMS, voice, and fake login portals (used in BEC).
Commercial risk scoring model by Breach Clarity that translates data breach contents into personal identity-theft risk for victims.
Metric introduced by CrowdStrike: average time from initial compromise to lateral movement (2024 global average: 1 hour 24 minutes).
Using a compromised browser as a foothold to attack internal network resources via WebRTC, WebSockets, or internal DNS (Cobalt Strike Beacon).
Weak encryption (e.g., single DES, short keys) that can be cracked with modern hardware (NIST bans in SP 800-131A).
Managed programs (HackerOne, Bugcrowd, YesWeHack) for crowdsourced vulnerability disclosure with rewards.
Intentionally planted backdoor disguised as a software bug (rare but documented in some nation-state cases).
Historical dial-up systems used in the 1980s–1990s by early hackers and phreaks; precursor to modern forums (2600 Magazine).
Malware or backdoor that has been publicly exposed and is no longer stealthy (e.g., after AV signatures are created).
Hardware-level memory encryption on modern CPUs (AMD SEV, Intel TDX) to protect VMs from hypervisor compromise.
Exploiting timing differences in application logic to infer hidden states (e.g., password reset token enumeration).
Bring Your Own VPN – employees using personal VPN services that may leak corporate traffic (forbidden in most policies).
Techniques and tools (PowerSploit, Metasploit modules) to escalate from medium to high integrity without UAC prompt on Windows.
Successor payload of BazarLoader, used by Ryuk/Conti for initial access (KPMG Threat Intelligence).
Extended BGP attribute used for traffic engineering and sometimes abused for remote-triggered blackholing (RTBH).
Using legitimately signed binaries (LOLBins) to execute malicious code while appearing trusted (MITRE T1218).
Using inter-keystroke timing as a behavioral biometric for continuous authentication.
Exploiting integer overflows/underflows via bitwise operations in unsafe languages (CWE-682).
Machine learning models where internal logic is not interpretable (opposite of white-box), creating security and compliance risks (NIST AI RMF).
2023 zero-click iOS exploit chain used by NSO Pegasus to install spyware via iMessage (Citizen Lab, Apple).
Advanced Persistent Threat combining cyber and physical operations (e.g., Stuxnet’s air-gap jump via USB).
Mining pool attack where miners submit partial proofs but withhold full blocks to waste pool resources (Bitcoin).
Chinese APT group active since 2012, known for supply-chain attacks and zero-days (CrowdStrike naming).
Intel hardware feature that cryptographically verifies firmware before execution (part of Intel Boot Guard).
Devices or chips designed from the ground up with security features (e.g., Apple T2, Google Titan M).
Fast-flux (rapid DNS changes) and double-flux (DNS server changes) to hide C2 infrastructure.
Tricking browsers into autofilling credentials on fake but visually identical login forms.
Side-channel attack on RSA implementations via acoustic analysis of CPU during decryption (2014).
Hosting providers that deliberately ignore abuse complaints, used by cybercriminals (Spamhaus, HostExploit).
Short, high-intensity DDoS attack designed to overwhelm before mitigation activates (under 10 minutes).
Mobile overlay attack placing invisible buttons over legitimate UI to capture taps (Android, iOS).
Cloud encryption model where customer generates and manages encryption keys (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault).

The infrastructure, protocols, and techniques used by adversaries to maintain persistent communication with compromised systems, issue commands, update payloads, and exfiltrate data. Modern C2 uses HTTPS, DNS tunneling, WebSockets, or legitimate cloud services (GitHub, Dropbox, Telegram) for stealth (MITRE ATT&CK T1071, NIST SP 800-53 SI-4).
DNS resource record that specifies which Certificate Authorities are permitted to issue certificates for a domain, preventing mis-issuance (RFC 8659, adopted by all major CAs since 2019).
Critical remote code execution vulnerability in Broadcom cable modem chipsets affecting 200+ million devices worldwide, allowing full ISP-level takeover (Lyrebirds 2020).

Malicious injection of false information into a cache (DNS, web, CPU) causing systems to return incorrect data. Famous examples: Kaminsky DNS attack (2008), Kindred/Weber web cache deception (OWASP, RFC 7871).
UPnP vulnerability in billions of devices allowing subscription to malicious callbacks for DDoS amplification and internal network scanning (Akamai 2020).
Fake credentials, files, URLs, or AWS keys planted to detect intrusion. When accessed, they trigger immediate alerts (Thinkst Canary, Canarytokens.org).
A web page displayed before granting network access (hotels, airports). Frequently abused for credential phishing or MitM (EvilPortal, WiFi Pineapple).
Competitive cybersecurity exercises where teams solve challenges in exploitation, forensics, crypto, reverse engineering, and web security (DEFCON, Pwn2Own, HackTheBox).
Leading endpoint detection and response (EDR) platform (now VMware Carbon Black Cloud) known for behavioral blocking and attack chain visualization.
The illegal use of stolen credit card data to make fraudulent purchases or create fake accounts (FBI IC3).
Credit card fraud without physical card presentation (online, phone), the most common e-commerce fraud type (Nilson Report 2025).
2012 Internet Census using default credentials on embedded devices, mapped entire IPv4 space (still one of the largest unauthorized scans ever).
HTTP response splitting attack by injecting \r\n into headers to create additional responses or XSS (CRLF → HTTP Response Splitting, OWASP).
Cartoon-themed phishing kits used by Russian-speaking actors (2024–2025) targeting banks with high conversion rates.
Physical token using visual one-time codes displayed on an e-ink screen, resistant to MitM (CASQUE SNR).
Romance scam using fake personas to extract money or data (also called romance scam).
Attack on AES-CBC where flipping a ciphertext bit predictably flips the corresponding plaintext bit after decryption (used in XML encryption attacks).
ISO/IEC standard for interoperable biometric data formats (ISO/IEC 19785).
Supply-chain attack on 2.7 million users where legitimate CCleaner installer was replaced with a backdoored version by Chinese APT (Avast/Piriform, Cisco Talos).
Landmark 2018 privacy law granting California residents rights to know, delete, and opt-out of sale of personal data (effective 2020, amended by CPRA 2023).
Vendor-neutral cloud security certification from Cloud Security Alliance covering CSA guidance and ENISA recommendations.
Recovery and analysis of video surveillance footage, including enhancement, timeline reconstruction, and metadata extraction (SWGDE Best Practices).
U.S. federal program providing real-time asset visibility, configuration management, and vulnerability assessment (CISA CDM).
Taking over a domain’s DNS to point CDN records (Cloudflare, Akamai) to attacker-controlled servers (e.g., MyEtherWallet 2018).
Telephony metadata logs abused in SIM swapping and social engineering attacks.
Popular entry-level offensive security certification focusing on penetration testing methodology (EC-Council).
IMSI catcher / Stingray device that impersonates legitimate cell towers to intercept calls, SMS, and location (Harris Corporation, FBI).
Hardcoding expected server certificate or public key in applications to prevent MitM with rogue CAs (HPKP deprecated → Certificate Transparency + pinning).
Public logs of all issued TLS certificates to detect mis-issuance (Google CT, RFC 6962).
Gold-standard information security certification from (ISC)² covering 8 domains (2024 version).

Living-off-the-land binary (LOLBin) abused to download files, decode Base64, and bypass AppLocker (MITRE ATT&CK T1140).
Intel hardware-enforced CFI to prevent ROP attacks (part of Tiger Lake+ CPUs).
Block cipher mode turning AES into a self-synchronizing stream cipher, used in older protocols.
Similar to CBC, allows single-bit plaintext manipulation without key (less common than CBC attacks).
IETF group responsible for recommending cryptographic algorithms (e.g., Curve25519, ChaCha20).

Critical Azure Cosmos DB vulnerability allowing full tenant read/write access via Jupyter notebook misconfiguration (Wiz 2021).
High-speed AEAD cipher designed by Daniel J. Bernstein, now mandatory in TLS 1.3 and WireGuard (RFC 8439).
Threat emulation sandbox technology (now Infinity Threat Prevention).
Simple integrity check (CRC32, Adler-32) easily bypassed by attackers (not cryptographic).
Executive responsible for enterprise information security strategy and compliance.
Chinese-speaking threat actor targeting semiconductor and critical infrastructure in Taiwan (CyCraft 2021).
Physically removing NAND flash memory chip from a device and reading it with specialized hardware (mobile phone forensics).
Open-source side-channel attack platform for power analysis and fault injection (NewAE Technology).
Open-source browser project underlying Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Brave, and Opera.
Cloud-native SIEM and security analytics platform (now Google Security Operations).
U.S. 2022 legislation providing $52B for domestic semiconductor manufacturing and security (CHIPS and Science Act).
Google pays up to $250,000 for Chrome remote code execution zero-days via Project Zero and bug bounty.
U.S. DHS agency responsible for national cyber defense, vulnerability management, and critical infrastructure protection.
One of the largest commercial threat intelligence teams, publishes daily blogs and Snort rules.
Prioritized set of 18 (v8) or 20 (v7) defensive actions (formerly SANS Top 20).
(ISC)² concentration for security management professionals.
University of Toronto research lab exposing commercial spyware (Pegasus, Circles, FinFisher).
Facebook/Meta policy team (now Elections Operations) fighting disinformation and coordinated inauthentic behavior.
Lockheed Martin 7-phase model: Recon → Weaponization → Delivery → Exploitation → Installation → C2 → Actions on Objectives.
Extremely active RaaS group exploiting zero-days (GoAnywhere, MOVEit) and running double-extortion (FBI Flash 2023).
Open-source antivirus engine widely used on mail gateways and Linux systems.
Covert cyber activity with high operational security (OPSEC) to avoid detection (nation-state level).
Unencrypted data (opposite of ciphertext).
Automated or human-driven invalid clicks on online ads to deplete competitor budgets or inflate revenue.
Mutual TLS where client presents X.509 certificate (802.1X, smart cards).
HTTP Request Smuggling variant exploiting differences between frontend and backend parsing (James Kettle, PortSwigger).
1993 NSA proposal for mandatory key escrow backdoor in all telephones (defeated by privacy advocates).
Security policy enforcement point between users and cloud services (McAfee MVISION, Netskope, Zscaler).
Consumer and enterprise zero-trust VPN replacement using WireGuard protocol.
Attack abusing misconfigured cloud services (S3 buckets, Azure blobs) for C2 or data exfiltration.
Continuous assessment of cloud configuration against best practices (Prisma Cloud, Orca, Wiz).
.NET execution environment vulnerable to type confusion and JIT spraying attacks.
Central repository of IT assets and their relationships (ServiceNow, BMC).
Top-level key in AWS KMS hierarchy that never leaves the service.
PKCS#7 standard for signed and encrypted messages (S/MIME, code signing).
FIPS 140-2/3 validation by NIST/NVLAP labs.
Phishing technique using CNAME records to make malicious domains appear as legitimate subdomains (evilcorp-com[.]security-updates[.]net).
Gartner term combining CSPM, CWPP, CI/CD security, and runtime protection (Prisma Cloud, Aqua, Sysdig).
ISACA framework for governance and management of enterprise IT (COBIT 2019).
Legitimate red-team framework heavily abused by ransomware and APTs (Beacon is the most detected payload 2021–2025).
Deprecated .NET permission model replaced by click-once trust.
Inserting malicious code into a program (SQLi, command injection, deserialization).
Cryptographic signing of executables and scripts to prove authenticity and integrity (Microsoft Authenticode, Apple Gatekeeper).
DRAM remanence attack recovering encryption keys from powered-off memory (Princeton 2008).
Windows registry attack replacing legitimate COM object CLSIDs with malicious DLLs (MITRE T1546.015).
Executing arbitrary OS commands via unsanitized application input (OWASP Top 10 A03:2021).
International standard (ISO/IEC 15408) for computer security certification (EAL1–EAL7).
Structured naming scheme for software, OS, and hardware (NIST NVD).
Standard for assessing vulnerability severity (v3.1 base score 0–10, v4.0 released 2023).
The process of fully eradicating attacker presence after a breach (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2).
Primary U.S. federal anti-hacking statute (18 U.S.C. § 1030).
UK law criminalizing unauthorized access and modification.
Hardware-based TEEs (Intel SGX, AMD SEV, AWS Nitro Enclaves) protecting data in use.
Gradual deviation from secure baseline causing vulnerabilities (detected by CSPM, CDM).
Message authentication without encryption (IPsec AH, DNSSEC).
Isolating affected systems to prevent spread (NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2).
Breaking out of a container (Docker, Kubernetes) to the host OS (CVE-2019-5736 runc, CVE-2022-0185).
Distributed proxy servers for faster content delivery; also used for DDoS protection (Cloudflare, Akamai, Fastly).
HTTP header mitigating XSS and data injection by whitelisting allowed resources (CSP Level 3).

U.S. federal information requiring protection but not classified (NIST SP 800-171).
Attack forcing a server to set attacker-controlled cookies via header injection.

Theft of trade secrets via hacking (APT10 CloudHopper, Operation Aurora).

Block cipher mode turning AES into a stream cipher with parallel encryption (NIST SP 800-38A).

Massive increase in phishing, ransomware, and supply-chain attacks exploiting pandemic (Interpol, FBI alerts 2020–2022).
Balanced Password-Authenticated Key Exchange resistant to precomputation (RFC 9382).
Official list of CPE names maintained by NIST (cpe.mitre.org).
MITRE ATT&CK tactic (TA0006) including dumping, stealing, forging credentials.
Extracting passwords/hashes from memory, registry, or files (Mimikatz, LSASS dumping).
Automated login attempts using leaked username/password pairs (OWASP Automated Threats).
MITRE technique T1555 – extracting saved passwords from browsers, KeePass, 1Password.
Systems whose disruption would have severe national impact (power grid, water, finance – protected by CISA, EU NIS Directive).
Cryptographic keys and secrets requiring highest protection (FIPS 140-3).
Mechanism allowing restricted resources to be requested from another domain (misconfiguration leads to data theft).
Attack tricking authenticated users into performing unwanted actions (OWASP Top 10).
Code injection into web pages viewed by other users (reflected, stored, DOM-based – OWASP Top 10).
Platforms like HackerOne, Bugcrowd, Synack paying ethical hackers for vulnerabilities.
Services (Tornado Cash, ChipMixer) obfuscating transaction trails (sanctioned by OFAC).
Unauthorized use of victim devices to mine cryptocurrency (Coinhive, XMRig).
Destroying encryption keys to render data unrecoverable (NIST SP 800-88).
One-way function producing fixed-size digest (SHA-256, SHA-3).
Hardware/software implementing approved algorithms (FIPS 140-validated).
PRNG suitable for keys and nonces (Fortuna, Yarrow, /dev/urandom).
First widespread ransomware (2013) using RSA-2048, extorted millions in Bitcoin.
Secure deletion by destroying the encryption key (also called crypto-erase).
Organization handling security incidents (FIRST.org members).
Executive overseeing physical and information security.
See Content Security Policy.
Global scoreboard and archive for Capture The Flag competitions.
Evidence-based knowledge about threats, actors, TTPs, and IOCs.
Open-source automated malware analysis system.
MITRE-maintained dictionary of public vulnerabilities (cve.mitre.org).
Organizations authorized to assign CVE IDs (MITRE, GitHub, Apple, etc.).
Critical remote code execution in Apache Log4j 2 affecting millions of Java applications (Dec 2021).
Zoho ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus unauthenticated RCE used by APT groups.
Spring Framework RCE similar to Log4Shell (March 2022).
Barracuda ESG zero-day exploited by Chinese actors for months.
OpenSSH Use-after-free allowing remote code execution (fixed 2024).
Windows Wi-Fi driver RCE used in active attacks (Patch Tuesday June 2024).
OpenSSH remote code execution on glibc systems (July 2024).
Windows TCP/IP IPv6 RCE used by Chinese actors (August 2024).
Latest version of Common Vulnerability Scoring System (released November 2023).
Security for VMs, containers, and serverless (CrowdStrike Falcon, Prisma Cloud Compute).
Identifying the real-world actor behind an attack (very difficult, often probabilistic).
See CKC.
Integration of computation, networking, and physical processes (smart grid, ICS).
Ability to prepare for, withstand, and recover from cyber attacks (NIST SP 800-160).
Gartner concept for decentralized, interoperable security architecture.
Registering domains similar to trademarks for profit or phishing (UDRP complaints).
Encrypted data (opposite of plaintext).
Attack with access only to encrypted data (hardest cryptanalytic attack).

The set of infrastructure, protocols, tools, and techniques used by threat actors to maintain persistent communication with compromised systems inside a victim network. C2 enables issuing new commands, updating malware, exfiltrating data, and pivoting. Modern C2 frequently masquerades as legitimate traffic via HTTPS, DNS tunneling, WebSockets, cloud services (GitHub, Discord, Slack, OneDrive), or even legitimate enterprise tools (Teams, ServiceNow). MITRE ATT&CK T1071, T1090, T1105, T1573 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev.5 SI-4).

A DNS resource record (RFC 8659) that restricts which Certificate Authorities are allowed to issue certificates for a domain. It acts as a fail-safe against mis-issuance or rogue CAs. Example: example.com CAA 0 issue letsencrypt.org. Mandatory for many CAs since 2019 (Google Trust Services, DigiCert, Sectigo).

Critical buffer overflow in Broadcom chipset firmware used in more than 200 million cable modems worldwide. Allowed remote attackers to execute code as root from the Internet. Discovered by Lyrebirds (Denmark) in 2020; many ISPs took months to patch.

The malicious insertion of false information into a cache (DNS cache, web cache, CPU cache). Famous examples: Dan Kaminsky DNS cache poisoning (2008), PortSmacker HTTP cache poisoning, and recent Web Cache Deception attacks (OWASP, James Kettle research).

UPnP SUBSCRIBE vulnerability affecting billions of IoT and network devices that allowed attackers to register malicious callbacks for massive DDoS reflection/amplification (up to 34×) and internal network discovery (Akamai 2020).

Decoy credentials, files, documents, URLs, DNS records, or AWS API keys intentionally planted in an environment. When touched, they immediately alert defenders via email, webhook, or SIEM. Thinkst Canarytokens is the most widely used implementation (thinkst.com).

A web page shown before granting Internet access on public Wi-Fi (hotels, airports, coffee shops). Frequently abused by attackers via rogue access points or DNS hijacking to serve phishing pages or perform MitM (WiFi Pineapple, EvilPortal).

Competitive cybersecurity exercises where participants solve challenges in categories such as web exploitation, reverse engineering, cryptography, forensics, and pwnables. Major events: DEF CON CTF, Pwn2Own, HackTheBox, CTFtime.org.
Endpoint detection and response (EDR) platform renowned for behavioral prevention, attack chain visualization, and live response capabilities. Now part of VMware Carbon Black Cloud.

The criminal process of verifying and using stolen credit-card data for fraudulent purchases, gift-card generation, or money laundering. Carding forums remain a core part of the cybercrime economy (FBI IC3).
Credit-card fraud that occurs without physical presentation of the card (online, phone, mail order). The dominant form of payment fraud globally (Nilson Report 2024–2025).

A massive unauthorized scan of the entire IPv4 address space using default credentials on embedded devices. While ethically questionable, it produced one of the most complete Internet maps ever created.
HTTP response splitting attack (CRLF = %0d%0a) that injects additional headers or entire responses, enabling cache poisoning, XSS, or session fixation (OWASP, RFC 7230).
Hardware token that displays visual one-time passwords via e-ink screen and challenge-response, providing true two-factor resistant to MitM (CASQUE SNR, UK).
Romance scam variant that builds long-term fake relationships to extract money, gift cards, or cryptocurrency (also known as “pig butchering” in Chinese-speaking groups).

Attack on AES-CBC where flipping a bit in ciphertext predictably flips the corresponding plaintext bit after decryption. Exploited in attacks on XML encryption, TLS padding, etc. Mitigated by authenticated encryption (AEAD).
Nation-state attack (APT17/Axiom) that backdoored the official 32-bit CCleaner 5.33 installer, affecting 2.7 million machines (Avast/Piriform, Cisco Talos).

California privacy law (effective 2020, strengthened by CPRA 2023) giving residents rights to know, delete, correct, and opt-out of sale of personal data. Model for many U.S. state laws (Virginia CDPA, Colorado CPA, etc.).
Vendor-neutral cloud security certification from Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) based on CSA Guidance v4 and ENISA recommendations.

Recovery, enhancement, authentication, and timeline reconstruction of surveillance video footage. Includes metadata extraction, frame-rate analysis, and deepfake detection (SWGDE Best Practices for Digital Video Evidence).
U.S. federal program managed by CISA that provides agencies with real-time asset discovery, vulnerability management, and configuration monitoring (CDM Dashboard).
Compromising a domain’s DNS records to point CDN endpoints (Cloudflare, Akamai, Fastly) to attacker-controlled origins. Notable incident: MyEtherWallet DNS hijack via BGP (2018).
Telephony metadata (who called whom, when, duration) frequently exploited in SIM-swapping attacks and social engineering.
Entry-to-mid level offensive security certification from EC-Council focusing on penetration testing methodology and tools.
Device that impersonates legitimate cell towers to intercept calls, SMS, and location data. Used by law enforcement and nation-states (Harris Corporation Stingray, FBI).

Application-level defense that hard-codes expected server certificate or public key, preventing MitM even with trusted CAs. HPKP was deprecated; modern implementations use Certificate Transparency + static pinning.
System of publicly auditable logs (Google, DigiCert, Sectigo) that record every TLS certificate issuance to detect mis-issuance (RFC 6962, Chrome policy since 2018).
The Center for Internet Security’s prioritized list of 18 defensive safeguards (formerly 20 controls) that form the baseline for most compliance frameworks (NIST CSF, PCI DSS, HIPAA).
The gold-standard information security certification from (ISC)² covering eight domains (2021–2024 version includes cloud, DevSecOps, zero trust).

Critical session-token disclosure vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway that allowed unauthenticated attackers to hijack active sessions. Exploited in the wild from August 2023 (Citrix, Mandiant).

Highly active Russian-speaking ransomware-as-a-service group famous for exploiting zero-days in MOVEit Transfer (2023), GoAnywhere MFT, and PaperCut. Known for double extortion and aggressive leak site (FBI Flash Alerts).
UI redressing attack that tricks users into clicking invisible elements by overlaying transparent iframes (OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet, Facebook Likejacking 2010–2011).
HTTP Request Smuggling variant exploiting differences in how frontend and backend parse message boundaries (James Kettle, PortSwigger 2021).

Security enforcement point that sits between users and cloud services, providing visibility, data loss prevention, threat protection, and compliance (Gartner category; vendors: Netskope, Zscaler, Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps).
Automated tools that continuously assess cloud configurations against benchmarks (CIS, NIST, vendor-specific) and remediate drift (Prisma Cloud, Orca Security, Wiz).
Gartner term combining CSPM, CWPP, CI/CD security, API security, and runtime protection into a unified platform (Palo Alto Prisma Cloud, Aqua Security, Sysdig).
See above – the converged future of cloud security tooling.

Commercial penetration-testing framework (now Fortra) whose Beacon implant is the most abused post-exploitation tool by ransomware groups and APTs worldwide (2020–2025). Detection signatures focus on default malleable C2 profiles.
EV or standard certificates used to sign executables, scripts, and installers to prove authenticity and integrity (Microsoft Authenticode, Apple Developer ID, Adobe AIR).

Physical attack that recovers RAM contents (including encryption keys) after rapid power-off by cooling DRAM modules (Princeton University 2008; still relevant for BitLocker/ FileVault without TPM pinning).
Exploitation of unsanitized user input to execute arbitrary operating system commands (OWASP Top 10 A03:2021 Injection).
International standard (ISO/IEC 15408) for computer security evaluation with Evaluation Assurance Levels (EAL1–EAL7). Used primarily in government and defense procurement.
Standard dictionary and identifier system for publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities maintained by MITRE and sponsored by CISA.
Standardized 0–10 scoring system for vulnerability severity. v3.1 widely used; v4.0 released November 2023 with improved threat and environmental metrics (FIRST.org).
