Proactive or post-incident engagement to determine whether an environment is currently compromised (Mandiant Red Team Assessment, CrowdStrike Falcon OverWatch, Microsoft Detection and Response Team – DART).
Primary U.S. federal anti-hacking law (18 U.S.C. § 1030). Frequently used in criminal and civil cases against researchers and insiders.
Hardware-based trusted execution environments (Intel SGX, AMD SEV-SNP, AWS Nitro Enclaves) that protect data while in use from cloud providers and privileged software.
Deep file sanitization technology that strips potentially malicious active content (macros, JavaScript, embeds) from documents and reconstructs clean versions (Votiro, Deep Secure, Menlo Security).
HTTP response header that mitigates XSS and data injection by declaring allowed sources for scripts, styles, images, etc. CSP3 adds nonce and hash-based whitelisting.
Gartner 2022–2025 framework consisting of five stages: Scoping, Discovery, Prioritization, Validation, Mobilization. Replaces periodic pentesting.
Compiler and runtime enforcement that ensures execution follows the intended control-flow graph, preventing most ROP/JOP attacks (Microsoft CFG, Clang CFI, Intel CET).
Forcing a server to set attacker-controlled cookies by injecting Set-Cookie headers, often via HTTP response splitting or misconfigured CORS.
Allowing any origin (Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *) while also allowing credentials, enabling unauthorized API access from malicious sites.
Extracting usernames, hashes, tickets, or tokens from memory, registry, or files (Mimikatz, LSASS dumping, Kerberoasting, DCSync).
Large-scale automated login attempts using username/password pairs leaked from previous breaches (OWASP Automated Threats, Akamai State of the Internet).
Attack that tricks an authenticated user’s browser into performing unwanted actions on a trusted site (OWASP Top 10 A01:2021 Broken Access Control).
Injection of malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Types: Reflected, Stored, DOM-based (OWASP Top 10 A03:2021 Injection).
Unauthorized use of victim devices (browsers, servers, IoT) to mine cryptocurrency (Coinhive 2017–2019, XMRig campaigns).
Rendering data unrecoverable by securely destroying the encryption key while keeping ciphertext (NIST SP 800-88r1).
PRNG suitable for cryptographic purposes (Windows CNG BCryptGenRandom, Linux getrandom(), /dev/urandom with proper entropy).
Open-source automated dynamic malware analysis system widely used for detonating samples in isolated virtual environments.
Remote code execution in Apache Log4j 2 via JNDI lookup message substitution. One of the most severe vulnerabilities ever disclosed (Dec 2021, CVSS 10.0).
Session token leakage in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway allowing session hijacking without authentication (Oct 2023).
Windows Wi-Fi driver remote code execution vulnerability actively exploited in 2024 (Patch Tuesday June 2024).
2023–2025 U.S. congressional commission updating the original 2020 recommendations with focus on layered cyber deterrence and resilience.

The portion of a Windows security descriptor that specifies which users or groups are granted or denied access to an object (file, registry key, AD object, printer). Each Access Control Entry (ACE) contains a Security Identifier (SID), access mask (read/write/execute/full), flags (inherit/object), and type (allow/deny). DACLs implement true Discretionary Access Control – the owner decides. Misconfigurations are the #1 cause of Windows privilege escalation (Microsoft Docs, MITRE ATT&CK T1222).

An attack that disrupts the availability of a target system or network by overwhelming it with traffic from multiple compromised sources (botnets, IoT devices, reflection servers). Modern DDoS exceeds 3 Tbps (2024–2025) and includes application-layer (L7) and carpet-bombing techniques (Cloudflare, Akamai, NETSCOUT ATLAS).

Malware technique that algorithmically generates thousands of pseudo-random domain names daily so the malware can locate its current C2 server even if domains are sinkholed. Used by Conficker, Kraken, Zeus, and most modern ransomware families (MITRE ATT&CK T1483).

Systems that identify, monitor, and block sensitive data (PII, PCI, PHI, source code) from leaving the organization via endpoint, network, or cloud channels. Modern DLP uses content inspection, contextual analysis, and exact data matching (Symantec, Forcepoint, Microsoft Purview).

Email authentication protocol (RFC 7489) that combines SPF and DKIM, then tells receiving servers what to do with failing messages (quarantine/reject) and provides visibility reports. Essential defense against CEO fraud and spoofing (dmarc.org, Global Cyber Alliance).

Technique for exfiltrating data or establishing C2 by encoding payloads inside DNS queries and responses. Bypasses most firewalls because DNS is almost always allowed outbound (MITRE ATT&CK T1071.004, tools: dnscat2, Iodine).

Windows cryptography API that protects user and machine secrets (passwords, EFS keys, RDP credentials) using keys derived from the user’s login password or machine master key. Frequently abused by malware via Mimikatz DPAPI offline decryption (Microsoft Docs).
Amplified DDoS that spoofs the victim’s IP address when querying open recursive servers (DNS, NTP, SSDP, Memcached). Amplification factors can reach 50,000× (e.g., Memcached 1.5 Tbps attack 2018).

Hardware-enforced one-way network link (optical or electrical) that physically permits data to flow only in one direction. Used in critical infrastructure (SCADA, nuclear) to prevent exfiltration while allowing logs/updates (Owl Cyber Defense, Waterfall Security).
Technique where malware writes C2 addresses to a pre-agreed public location (GitHub repo, pastebin, DNS TXT record) that is read by the implant instead of hard-coding domains (used by APT29, OilRig).
Wi-Fi attack that forges 802.11 deauth frames to disconnect clients from legitimate access points, forcing reconnection to rogue APs (MITRE ATT&CK T1464, tools: aireplay-ng, MDK4).

AI-generated synthetic media (video, audio, images) that realistically depicts people saying or doing things they never did. Weaponized for disinformation, fraud, and non-consensual pornography (DARPA Media Forensics, NIST IR 8310).
Layered security approach that uses multiple, overlapping controls (perimeter, network, host, application, data) so the failure of one does not compromise the entire system (NSA, NIST SP 800-53).
Formerly Microsoft Defender ATP – cloud-native EDR with behavioral blocking, ASR rules, automated investigation, and integration with Microsoft 365 Defender.
Incremental Certificate Revocation List containing only changes since the last base CRL, reducing bandwidth for large PKIs.
Network segment placed between two firewalls that exposes public-facing services (web, mail, DNS) while protecting the internal LAN (NIST SP 800-41).
SHA-1 certificates officially forbidden by all major browsers and CAs since January 2017 after practical collision attack (SHAttered, Google/CWI 2017).
Exploiting weak or predictable entropy sources (e.g., PID-based ASLR, low-entropy /dev/urandom at boot) to defeat randomization defenses.
Insecure deserialization vulnerability (CWE-502) that allows remote code execution by sending crafted objects (Java, .NET, Python pickle, PHP). Top 10 OWASP since 2017.
Isolated sandbox environment (physical or virtual) for safely executing and observing malicious files or URLs (FireEye, Cuckoo, ANY.RUN).
Windows 10/11 virtualization-based security (VBS) features that isolate LSASS (Credential Guard) and block unsigned code (Device Guard / WDAC).
Analytical framework that maps adversary, infrastructure, capability, and victim for every intrusion event (CALT, 2013).
Side-channel attack that recovers cryptographic keys by statistically analyzing power consumption patterns during encryption/decryption (Paul Kocher, 1999).
Attack that accesses files outside the web root by manipulating paths with ../ sequences (OWASP Top 10 A01:2021).
Deliberately false or misleading information spread with malicious intent (opposite of misinformation) (EUvsDisinfo, CISA).
Exploitation of legitimate Windows applications that load DLLs from the current working directory instead of System32 (MITRE ATT&CK T1574.002, tools: HijackLibs).
Lightweight DNS forwarder and DHCP server widely used in routers and IoT devices. Multiple critical vulnerabilities over the years (DNSpooq 2021).
Breaking out of a container to the host OS via kernel exploits, misconfigured capabilities, or privileged containers (CVE-2019-5736 runc breakout).
Technique that hides the true endpoint by using a different domain in the HTTP Host header than in the SNI/TLS handshake. Used by Signal and Psiphon; largely mitigated by CDNs in 2018–2020.
See DGA above.
Unauthorized transfer or modification of a domain’s registration records, often via registrar account compromise or social engineering (Sea Turtle campaign 2019).
NSA-developed backdoor implant deployed by EternalBlue (Shadow Brokers leak). Used in WannaCry and NotPetya propagation.
Malware infection that occurs simply by visiting a compromised website, without user interaction (exploit kits: Angler, RIG, Magnitude).
Deliberately weakened NIST-standardized pseudorandom number generator containing an NSA backdoor (exposed by Snowden documents, 2013).
Chinese APT group (APT27/Emissary Panda) active since 2009, known for PlugX and custom malware.
Physical social engineering technique of searching trash for sensitive documents, passwords, or access cards (Kevin security awareness training staple).
Black-box testing that interacts with a running application to find vulnerabilities (SQLi, XSS, CSRF) without source code (OWASP ZAP, Burp Suite Scanner).
Real-time obfuscation of sensitive data in database query results based on user privileges (SQL Server, Oracle, Snowflake).
Technique that forces a process to load a malicious DLL (CreateRemoteThread + LoadLibrary, reflective injection, APC injection).

Hardware-enforced memory protection (NX/XD bit) that marks memory pages as non-executable, preventing classic buffer overflow code execution. Bypassed via ROP, JIT spraying, or ACG violations (Microsoft, Intel/AMD).
Technique where stolen data is sent back to the attacker using the same encrypted C2 channel (HTTPS, DNS, WebSocket). Most common exfil method in 2024–2025 (MITRE ATT&CK T1041).
Software installed on laptops/desktops that monitors clipboard, USB, printing, cloud sync, and screenshots to prevent sensitive data leakage (Symantec DLP, Forcepoint, Digital Guardian).
Traditional digital forensics performed on powered-off devices (hard drives, phones, USBs) using write-blockers and imaging tools (EnCase, FTK, Autopsy).
Fake privileged account (e.g., AWS root with fake keys) seeded in code repositories or password vaults to trigger alerts when used (Canarytokens, AWS Honey Tokens).
Examination of packet payload (not just headers) for malware signatures, protocol anomalies, or policy violations. Used by NGFWs and nation-state surveillance (Palo Alto, Cisco Firepower, Sandvine).
Factory usernames/passwords left unchanged on devices (admin/admin, root/toor, pi/raspberry). Still the #1 cause of IoT botnet recruitment (Mirai, Reaper, Satori).
MITRE ATT&CK tactic (TA0005) that includes obfuscated files, masquerading, timestomping, rootkits, and anti-sandbox techniques.
U.S. companies that support DoD contracts. Subject to CMMC (Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification) requirements since 2021.
DoD missions to defend military networks, including internal hunt teams and active countermeasures.
Cryptographic keys with intentionally weak parameters (short length, predictable structure) used in some nation-state implants for easier recovery.
Active Directory account with elevated privileges granted via delegation instead of group membership (common in Exchange, DNS, or certificate services – frequent target of attackers).
Malware written in Delphi (e.g., Emotet, TrickBot, QakBot) that is harder to reverse-engineer due to heavy runtime packing and anti-analysis.
Palo Alto Networks SOAR platform for security orchestration, automation, and response with playbooks and case management.
Supply-chain attack that prevents legitimate customers from purchasing products (e.g., ticket scalping bots, PS5/Xbox scalping 2020–2023).
Supply-chain attack that exploits package managers (npm, PyPI, RubyGems) by uploading malicious packages with higher version numbers than internal private packages (Alex Birsan, 2021).
Military-grade portable public key infrastructure used in tactical environments where connectivity to central CAs is unreliable (DoD SIPRNet tokens).
Officially forbidden by PCI DSS 4.0 (March 2025 deadline) and all major browsers since 2020–2021 due to known weaknesses (BEAST, POODLE, SLOTH).
2013–2014 campaign that took down major gaming sites (League of Legends, EA, DOTA2) using NTP reflection – one of the first public “DDoS for lulz” groups.
Running user desktops in VMs (VDI) or containers (Windows 365, Citrix, VMware Horizon) to improve security and management.
Network address translation that rewrites the destination IP/port of incoming packets (used in port forwarding and load balancing).
Variant of Digital Signature Algorithm with deterministic k value (RFC 6979) to prevent side-channel and fault attacks.
Enforcement of security posture (patch level, encryption, antivirus) before allowing network or cloud access (Intune, Jamf, Cisco ISE).
Integration of security practices into DevOps pipelines (shift-left security) using SAST, DAST, SCA, IaC scanning, and policy-as-code (GitLab, Bridgecrew, Snyk).
Open-source and commercial tools that identify DGA-generated domains via linguistic patterns and NXDomain rates (Cisco Umbrella, NXDomain-based detection).
Modular banking trojan sold on underground forums (2015–2020) with webinjects, form grabbing, and VNC capabilities.
Iranian attackers compromised Dutch CA DigiNotar and issued rogue certificates for google.com, microsoft.com, etc., leading to full distrust and bankruptcy of the CA.
Electronic document that binds a public key to an identity using a trusted Certificate Authority (X.509 v3 standard).
The initial person (IT staff, law enforcement) who identifies, preserves, and documents digital evidence at a scene (NIST SP 800-86).
Technologies that restrict usage of proprietary content (Widevine, FairPlay, PlayReady) – frequently targeted by piracy groups.
Asymmetric signature scheme based on discrete logarithm problem. Deprecated by NIST in favor of ECDSA (FIPS 186-4).
Rootkit technique that modifies kernel data structures (EPROCESS, ETHREAD) to hide processes or drivers from user-mode tools (FU rootkit, 2005).
Special boot mode for Active Directory domain controllers with a local administrator account (often forgotten, high-value target).
Commercial offerings on dark web that create and spread fake news, deepfakes, and bot campaigns for hire.
Full-disk or volume encryption (BitLocker, FileVault, LUKS, VeraCrypt) that protects data at rest from physical theft.
Broader term than blockchain that includes DAGs (IOTA, Hedera Hashgraph) and permissioned ledgers (Hyperledger Fabric, R3 Corda).
Lateral movement technique that jumps from compromised DMZ hosts (web servers) into the internal network via misconfigured firewalls or dual-homed servers.
Protocol that encrypts DNS traffic between client and resolver to prevent eavesdropping and tampering (OpenDNS, Cloudflare 1.1.1.1 with DoH/DoT).
U.S. Department of Defense mandate (2027 deadline) to implement zero-trust architecture across all classified and unclassified networks.
Exploitation of Active Directory trust relationships (parent-child, cross-forest, external) for privilege escalation (Trust Tickets, SID History attacks).
Cryptographic email authentication method that allows the receiver to verify the message was sent from an authorized domain (RFC 6376).
Compromise of one system that automatically triggers compromise of dependent systems (e.g., patch management server, backup server).
Open-source shellcode generator and loader that converts .NET, EXE, DLL, or VBS into position-independent code for reflective loading (TheWover, 2021).
Typo-squatting + homograph attack using visually similar Unicode characters (e.g., аpple.com with Cyrillic а).
Forcing a protocol or cipher suite to a weaker version (Logjam, FREAK, POODLE, Sweet32 attacks on SSL/TLS).
Russian APT group (Turla/Unit 42 naming) targeting energy sector and ICS since 2011 (Havex, CrashOverride industries).
MITRE ATT&CK technique (T1189) where victims are infected simply by visiting a legitimate but compromised website (watering hole attack).
Malware whose sole purpose is to download and execute a more sophisticated payload (Emotet dropper → QakBot → Cobalt Strike).
Software that is legitimate for red teaming but heavily abused by attackers (Cobalt Strike, Metasploit, BloodHound, PowerSploit, Mimikatz).
See earlier entry – Chinese APT known for long-term espionage using PlugX, HyperBro, and custom implants.
Self-signed or fake certificate used for testing or malicious interception (often flagged by EDR as suspicious).
Execution of malware in a controlled environment (sandbox, VM) to observe runtime behavior (Cuckoo, Joe Sandbox, ANY.RUN).
Zero-trust micro-segmentation at the workload level (Illumio, Guardicore, Akamai Enterprise Application Access).
Signing of scripts or macros at runtime (PowerShell Constrained Language Mode + AMSI bypass attempts).
Malware that resolves C2 domains at runtime using custom algorithms instead of hard-coded IPs (fast-flux, DGA).
Linux equivalent of DLL hijacking – preloading malicious shared objects via LD_PRELOAD or /etc/ld.so.preload.
Heap-based buffer overflows, use-after-free, double-free exploited via JavaScript engines or browsers (Chrome V8, Firefox SpiderMonkey).
Cloud or on-prem WAF that adapts rules in real time using behavioral analysis and threat intelligence (Imperva, Cloudflare, AWS WAF).
October 2016 DDoS that knocked out major sites (Twitter, Netflix, Reddit) via compromised IoT devices using default credentials.

Highly sophisticated banking trojan (2014–2016) famous for Man-in-the-Browser webinjects, VNC control, and bypassing two-factor authentication via transaction manipulation. Precursor to TrickBot/Emotet ecosystem.
Encrypted DNS protocol (RFC 8484) that tunnels DNS queries inside HTTPS to port 443, preventing ISP-level inspection and tampering (Cloudflare 1.1.1.1, Google 8.8.8.8, Firefox/Chrome native support).
Encrypted DNS protocol (RFC 7858) using TLS on port 853. Less adopted than DoH but preferred by some privacy advocates for clear separation (Quad9, AdGuard).
Attack that bypasses Same-Origin Policy by rapidly changing the IP returned for a malicious domain (e.g., 127.0.0.1 → attacker IP) allowing browser to access internal services (rbndr.es, OWASP).
Suite of extensions (RFC 4033–4035) that adds cryptographic signatures to DNS records to protect against cache poisoning and spoofing. Still only ~15–20% global adoption in 2025.
Technique that returns bogus IP (usually 127.0.0.1 or block page) for known malicious domains, effectively blocking C2 and malware downloads (Cisco Umbrella, Infoblox BloxOne, Microsoft Defender).
Legal requirement that certain data must remain within specific geographic borders (GDPR Article 3, China Cybersecurity Law, Russia Data Localization Law).
The concept that data is subject to the laws and governance of the country in which it is physically located, often conflicting with cloud multi-region storage.
Automated mechanism that releases data or triggers actions if the operator fails to check in (used by ransomware groups and whistleblowers).
Automated Active Directory privilege-escalation tool that finds misconfigurations and chains them into domain admin (Byt3bl33d3r, 2020).
Deliberate deployment of decoy systems, credentials, and data to detect, mislead, and study attackers (Attivo Networks, Thinkst Canary, Acalvio, TrapX).
Deep-learning-based endpoint protection that claims >99% prevention with <0.1% false positives using neural networks trained on billions of samples.
Techniques such as TLS encryption, domain fronting, or packet fragmentation used by malware to avoid NGFW detection.
Firewall or application control policy that blocks everything unless explicitly allowed (zero-trust principle).
Security Technical Implementation Guides – hardened configuration standards for DoD systems (Windows, RHEL, Cisco, Oracle, etc.).
The internal security team responsible for detection, response, monitoring, and hardening (as opposed to Red/Purple teams).
Certificate with extremely weak keys (512-bit RSA) or invalid fields used by some malware for fake HTTPS.
Active Directory attack where overly broad delegated permissions (e.g., on OU or GPO) are used to escalate privileges.
Single firewall rule or device that becomes a bottleneck and single point of failure between DMZ and internal network.

term: Denial of Service via Algorithmic Complexity (ReDoS)
definition: Regular expression denial-of-service where malicious input causes catastrophic backtracking (Evil Regex patterns in Node.js, Java, Python).
Open-source Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) and vulnerability management platform for tracking third-party components.
Large-scale honeypot/honeynet deployment across an enterprise to create a realistic-looking fake internal network.
Triple DES officially disallowed by PCI DSS 4.0 (June 2024) and NIST SP 800-131A due to 112-bit effective security.
Chinese kernel-level backdoor used by multiple APT groups (APT17, APT27, Deep Panda) since 2008.
Core function of modern SOCs: detect threats early and respond before material damage occurs.
Software build process that produces bit-for-bit identical binaries every time, enabling reproducible builds and supply-chain verification (Tor, Bitcoin Core).
Chinese APT41 toolset for ICS/SCADA environments discovered in 2023–2024 attacks on critical infrastructure.
Collecting dozens of browser/system attributes (canvas, WebGL, fonts, timezone, etc.) to uniquely identify and track users even without cookies (EFF Panopticlick, FingerprintJS).
Stack buffer overflow in gSOAP library affecting millions of IoT devices (Axis cameras, etc.) allowing remote code execution.
See earlier entry – modular banking trojan sold as malware-as-a-service.
Command-line DNS lookup tool frequently abused by attackers for reconnaissance and DNS tunneling.
Combined discipline of forensic preservation and real-time incident response (SANS FOR508/GCFA).
Tools that brute-force web directories and files to discover hidden admin panels, backups, and configuration files.
Linux kernel privilege-escalation vulnerability (5.8+) allowing overwrite of read-only files, including SUID binaries (Max Kellermann, 2022).
Linux kernel race condition allowing local privilege escalation via copy-on-write memory mapping (2016, still found unpatched in 2025).
Access control model where the resource owner decides permissions (UNIX file permissions, NTFS DACLs).
Whistleblower platform similar to WikiLeaks that publishes leaked datasets (BlueLeaks, Parler, Epik).
Windows vulnerability where applications search current directory before System32 for DLLs (MITRE T1574.001).
Using a compromised reverse proxy in the DMZ as a jump box into internal networks.
Reflection attack using open recursive DNS servers that return large responses (51× amplification common).
Encoding stolen data in DNS queries (subdomains) and sending to attacker-controlled authoritative server.
When a domain has DNSSEC enabled but records are misconfigured, causing complete resolution failure (often exploited for DoS).
Enterprise controls that block or redirect DNS over HTTPS to enforce corporate DNS filtering (Cisco Umbrella, NextDNS).
Windows Server 2012+ feature abused by attackers to create rogue DCs with full AD database.
Symmetric key shared between trusted Active Directory forests for cross-forest authentication (exportable via ntdsutil).
Ransomware that not only encrypts data but also exfiltrates it and threatens to publish (Maze, Conti, LockBit, ALPHV).
Chinese APT41 supply-chain attack that compromised official Korean construction software in 2024.
Banking trojan (2014–present) evolved from GameOver Zeus, famous for macro-enabled documents and webinjects.
Attack that changes victim’s home router DNS settings via malicious JavaScript on a compromised site.
Malware that writes itself to disk and immediately executes, then deletes the dropper (common in fileless attacks).
System with two network interfaces (one internal, one DMZ/Internet) – frequently used for pivoting if misconfigured.
Open-source tool that detects and blocks Cobalt Strike beacons based on malleable C2 profiles.
Leading provider of multi-factor authentication (now part of Cisco) famous for push-based Duo Push.
Dynamic DNS services abused by attackers to maintain C2 reachability on residential connections.
IBM-discovered 2015 campaign that combined Dyre trojan with phone-based social engineering to steal millions from enterprises.

Level 1–7 in Common Criteria (ISO/IEC 15408) that defines the depth and rigor of security evaluation. EAL4 is the highest mutually recognized level; EAL7 is for extremely high-risk environments (smart cards, military). Most commercial products are EAL2+ or EAL4+ (NIAP, BSI).
Framework used within 802.1X and PPP for negotiating authentication methods (EAP-TLS, EAP-TTLS, PEAP, EAP-FAST). EAP-TLS is the most secure (certificate-based) and recommended by NIST SP 800-208.

Extensible Authentication Protocol using TLS for mutual certificate-based authentication. Required for DoD, FIPS 140-3 medium environments, and zero-trust networks. Replaces insecure PEAP-MSCHAPv2 (Cisco, Microsoft, Aruba).

Security solution that continuously monitors endpoints, detects advanced threats using behavioral analytics, and provides incident response capabilities (CrowdStrike Falcon, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, SentinelOne, Carbon Black).
Techniques used by advanced malware and red teams to avoid detection (direct syscalls, unhooking NTDLL, ETW tampering, AMSI bypass, Sleepmasking). MITRE ATT&CK T1562, T1620.
Web-based frameworks (Angler, RIG, Magnitude, PurpleFox) that deliver exploits for browser and plugin vulnerabilities via drive-by downloads. Peaked 2014–2018, still active in 2025.

Deprecated Microsoft tool (2009–2017) that applied software mitigations (DEP, ASLR, certificate pinning) to older applications. Replaced by Windows 10+ built-in exploit protection and Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules.
EU agency responsible for cybersecurity policy, threat landscape reports, certification frameworks (EUCS, eIDAS), and the annual ENISA Threat Landscape (ETL) report.
2023–2024 campaign that exploited CVE-2021-21974 (OpenSLP) in unpatched VMware ESXi servers to encrypt virtual machines directly at the hypervisor level.
Low-level Windows telemetry system used by EDR for high-fidelity logging. Frequently tampered with by attackers (ETW patching, provider disabling) and restored by modern EDR (MITRE T1654).
NSA-developed SMBv1 remote code execution exploit leaked by Shadow Brokers in 2017. Weaponized in WannaCry, NotPetya, and countless ransomware attacks (still found unpatched in 2025).
Underground services that test and modify malware to evade specific EDR/AV products (TryCloudflare, CryptOMG, FUD-as-a-Service).
Windows Security log events for successful and failed logons. Core events monitored by SIEM and EDR for brute-force, pass-the-hash, and lateral movement detection.
Windows Event Log forwarding (WEF) or Windows Event Collector (WEC) used to centralize logs from endpoints to a SIEM. Frequently targeted by attackers to disable (wevtutil cl, service stop).

Physical attack where an attacker with brief unattended access installs hardware keyloggers, bootkits, or replaces drives (e.g., hotel room scenario). Defended by Secure Boot, TPM, and full-disk encryption with pre-boot auth.
Data breaches exceeding 1 exabyte (1 billion GB). First predicted by Gartner in 2024; closest real-world example is the 2023–2025 COMB (Compilation of Many Breaches) dataset approaching 500 TB.
Microsoft’s cloud email filtering service (part of Microsoft Defender for Office 365) that replaced Forefront. Still bypassed by advanced BEC actors using reply-chain spoofing.
Technique where data is exfiltrated over an encrypted channel that uses different keys for inbound/outbound (e.g., SSH port forwarding, reverse HTTPS beacons).
MITRE ATT&CK technique covering initial access via vulnerable web servers, VPNs, or OWA (ProxyShell, ProxyLogon, Citrix Bleed, MOVEit, etc.).

Highest-assurance TLS certificate requiring rigorous legal and physical verification of the organization. Visual green bar removed from browsers 2019–2021, but still required by some compliance frameworks.
Broader term than ransomware – includes any cyber attack that threatens to release, destroy, or block data unless payment is made (doxxing, DDoS extortion, wiper + leak threats).
Chinese APT41 reconnaissance and credential-theft framework discovered 2024–2025 targeting Southeast Asia and Taiwan government networks (Mandiant).
Privilege-escalation and persistence technique that queues an APC during process startup before anti-malware initializes (used by QakBot, IcedID).
Passive interception of communications (MITM, Wi-Fi sniffing, Bluetooth skimming). Defeated by end-to-end encryption (TLS, Signal Protocol).
Firmware and hardware supply-chain security company famous for discovering Bootkitty, MoonBounce, CosmicStrand, and LogoFAIL UEFI threats.
Protection of distributed compute nodes (5G MEC, IoT gateways, retail kiosks) that process data outside traditional data centers (NIST SP 1800-32).
Short-lived (2020–2021) but highly effective RaaS that succeeded Maze and used print-bombing, SEC filing threats, and aggressive leaks.
Firewall rules that restrict outbound traffic to only necessary protocols/ports/destinations. Critical defense against C2 and exfiltration (RFC 6092, BCP 38).
First ransomware specifically designed to kill ICS processes (Siemens, GE, Honeywell) before encryption (Dragos, 2020).
Formerly Endgame – open + commercial XDR/SIEM solution built on Elasticsearch stack with strong endpoint and cloud capabilities.
Protection of voting systems, voter registration databases, and campaign infrastructure from foreign interference (CISA, DHS, DEF CON Voting Village).
Public-key cryptography based on elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem. Offers same strength as RSA with much shorter keys (256-bit ECC ≈ 3072-bit RSA).
BEC technique where attackers silently monitor an existing legitimate email conversation and insert malicious replies/invoices (no malware required).
Non-removable SIM chip that can be reprogrammed over-the-air. Introduces new risks in carrier-level supply-chain attacks.
Open-source Snort/Suricata signatures maintained by Proofpoint for zero-day and fast-moving threats.
The “king of malware” (2014–2021, 2021–present) – modular banking trojan turned loader-as-a-service. Taken down Jan 2021, resurrected Nov 2021 via TrickBot infrastructure.
Post-exploitation framework (PowerShell/C#) popular 2016–2020, now largely replaced by Covenant, Sliver, and Cobalt Strike.

Windows registry key (HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System) that allows elevated processes to see mapped drives created by standard users – frequently abused for privilege escalation.
Malware or C2 that uses strong encryption (TLS, WireGuard, age) making network detection extremely difficult. Dominant trend 2023–2025.
Traditional antivirus + host firewall + device control. EPP + EDR = modern endpoint security stack (Gartner definition).
Using legitimately issued code-signing certificates (stolen or fraudulently obtained) to sign malware (Industroyer, NotPetya, Stuxnet components).
Measuring randomness in files or memory to detect packed/encrypted malware (binwalk, YARA entropy checks).
Other Shadow Brokers–leaked SMB exploits used alongside EternalBlue in 2017–2018 attacks.
Ancient (1999) buffer overflow in Qualcomm Eudora email client – one of the first widely exploited remote code execution bugs.
Rogue Wi-Fi access point that mimics a legitimate one to steal credentials or perform MitM (Karma attack, Wi-Fi Pineapple).
U.S. Biden administration order (May 2021) mandating SBOMs, zero trust, endpoint detection, and secure software development for federal systems.
MITRE technique (T1567) using legitimate cloud services (Google Drive, Dropbox, GitHub, Pastebin) to steal data.
Operating system and compiler protections: ASLR, DEP/NX, CFG, CET, Stack Canaries, SafeSEH, Shadow Stack.
Integrated security platform that collects and correlates data across endpoints, network, cloud, and identity (Palo Alto Cortex XDR, Microsoft 365 Defender, Trend Micro Vision One).
MITRE technique exploiting exposed RDP, VPN, Citrix, or VNC for initial access (BlueKeep, Citrix Bleed, Zoho ManageEngine chains).
Network detection and response (NDR) platform using wire data and machine learning for east-west traffic analysis.
Italian-made surveillance malware (2016) used against government officials, later sold commercially.
Phishing-as-a-Service platform that performs real-time reverse-proxy MitM on login pages (Adversary-in-the-Middle). Used in many 2023–2025 MFA bypass campaigns.
Open-source successor to Evilginx2 – advanced phishing framework for session hijacking and 2FA bypass.
Theoretical and real attacks that send malicious packets directly to PLCs (Triton/Trisis, PIPEDREAM/Incontroller).
Exfiltration tool used by Lazarus Group (2020–2023) capable of stealing files, credentials, and certificates from compromised servers.
High-performance database abused in supply-chain attacks because of its use in industrial and medical devices.

Critical privilege-escalation vulnerability in Microsoft Azure Service Fabric (Linux nodes) that allowed container escape to the cluster host. Actively exploited in 2022–2023 by Chinese and North Korean actors (Microsoft, Mandiant).

Open standard for passwordless authentication using public-key cryptography and hardware authenticators (YubiKey, Windows Hello, Google Titan). Supported by all major browsers and platforms since 2019 (FIDO Alliance, W3C WebAuthn).

Mexican/Spanish-speaking financially motivated group (also known as Elephant Beetle) active since at least 2016, specializing in long-term compromise of financial and retail organizations in Latin America using custom .NET backdoors.
General term for the interconnected groups (initial access brokers, ransomware affiliates, money-laundering services) that dominate cybercrime 2023–2025.
FireEye/Mandiant’s reverse-engineering and malware-analysis virtual machine packed with hundreds of tools (IDA, x64dbg, PEStudio, ProcDot, etc.).
Advanced memory-only dropper used by APT29 (Cozy Bear) in 2024–2025 diplomatic sector attacks. Uses Windows Filter Manager to inject into legitimate processes (Microsoft, 2025).
Open-source tool abused by attackers for internal network pivoting and C2 over legitimate-looking HTTPS traffic (fatedier/frp).
AccessData’s commercial digital-forensics suite used worldwide by law enforcement and enterprises for imaging, carving, indexing, and timeline analysis.
Chinese APT41 custom backdoor discovered in 2024 targeting textile and manufacturing sectors in Southeast Asia (CrowdStrike).
Open-source intrusion-prevention tool that monitors logs (SSH, web) and dynamically blocks attacking IPs via iptables/firewalld (widely used on Linux servers).
JavaScript downloader campaign active since 2018 that masquerades as browser/plugin updates and drops NetSupport RAT, Cobalt Strike, or ransomware.
North Korean (Lazarus) backdoor used since 2009, often delivered via HWP exploits targeting South Korean entities (NSA, 2017 Shadow Brokers leak).
Security-team burnout caused by excessive low-fidelity alerts, leading to missed real threats. Major issue in SIEM/EDR tuning (Gartner 2024–2025).
Technique that rapidly changes DNS A records (single-flux) or NS records (double-flux) to hide malicious infrastructure. Still used by botnets and phishing kits.
U.S. law requiring federal agencies to implement risk-based cybersecurity programs using NIST standards (800-53, 800-37 RMF).
Web vulnerability (LFI/RFI) that allows inclusion and execution of local or remote files (PHP include()/require(), often leading to RCE).
FTP over TLS/SSL – encrypts both command and data channels (explicit vs implicit). Largely replaced by SFTP.
Malware that lives only in memory or uses legitimate system tools (PowerShell, WMI, rundll32, regsvr32) to avoid disk-based detection (Kovter, Poweliks, Astaroth, 2020–2025 trend).
Windows kernel driver that hooks file operations (used by both legitimate AV/EDR and malicious rootkits – BlackLotus UEFI bootkit abused it in 2023).
Commercial surveillance spyware sold by Gamma Group to governments. Known for zero-day exploits and UEFI persistence (Citizen Lab, 2014–2024).
Collecting unique characteristics (HTTP headers, TLS JA3, canvas, WebGL, fonts) to track or identify targets even without cookies (Panopticlick, JA3/S, Akamai Bot Manager).
Cloud-delivered firewall and secure web gateway (Zscaler, Palo Alto Prisma Access, Cisco Umbrella).
Browser feature that isolates cookies and storage by top-level site to prevent cross-site tracking (Safari ITP, Firefox Total Cookie Protection).
Open-source residential proxy network used by Chinese actors for anonymized C2 and scanning (discovered 2024).
Protection of MDM/MAM solutions (Microsoft Intune, Jamf, MobileIron) that control thousands of corporate devices – high-value targets.
Cisco-developed runtime DDoS protection for OpenFlow SDN controllers (2015–2016 research, still relevant).
Lightweight .NET RAT sold on Russian forums since 2021, heavily used by FIN7/Carbanak successors.
Major DLP and CASB vendor known for behavioral UEBA and risk-adaptive protection.
Information-stealing malware sold as MaaS since 2016 – grabs credentials, screenshots, keystrokes, clipboard. Still top-10 most prevalent malware in 2025.
Heap buffer overflow exploited by Chinese and Russian actors in 2022–2023 against government and critical infrastructure targets.
Cryptographic property ensuring that compromise of long-term keys does not compromise past session keys (requires ephemeral Diffie-Hellman – mandatory in TLS 1.3).
Downgrade attack that forced export-grade 512-bit RSA keys in TLS by exploiting legacy U.S. crypto export rules.
ICS malware discovered by Dragos in 2024 that targets Modbus TCP devices (used in Ukrainian critical infrastructure attack, January 2024).
Automated software testing technique that feeds invalid/random data to find crashes and memory corruption bugs (AFL++, libFuzzer, Syzkaller).
The de-facto standard open-source port scanner and network discovery tool used by defenders and attackers alike since 1997.
Finnish cybersecurity company known for endpoint protection and one of the first to detect Stuxnet in the wild (2010).
Technique where attackers pose as legitimate software installers (Adobe Flash, codec packs) to trick users into running malware.
See above.
Physical-layer interception of fiber-optic cables (NSA FOXACID, GCHQ TEMPORA programs).
Digital-forensics tool specialized in carving files from raw disk images without filesystem metadata (Scalpel, Foremost, PhotoRec).
iOS and Android versions of FinFisher with zero-click capabilities via NSO-style exploits (2019–2024).
Pioneering incident-response and threat-intelligence company that discovered APT1, SolarWinds SUNBURST, and countless zero-days.
Threat-intelligence technique that flags domains, files, or IPs that appeared for the first time very recently (high indicator of malicious registration).
Highly advanced espionage toolkit discovered 2012 by Kaspersky – one of the most complex malware ever (20 MB, Lua scripting, USB infection).
First widespread macOS botnet (2011–2012) that infected >600,000 Macs via Java drive-by exploits.
Google’s open-source C2 communication framework used internally and by GRR Rapid Response.
Legitimate remote-administration tool (Ammyy Admin) whose leaked source code was weaponized by TA505 and others.
Android trojan family (2021–2024) that hijacked Facebook accounts via malicious apps on Google Play.
Attacker techniques to minimize evidence (clearing logs, timestomping, living-off-the-land binaries).
Exact data matching technique that fingerprints unstructured sensitive documents (designs, source code) instead of relying on regex.
Client-side supply-chain attack that injects malicious JavaScript into e-commerce checkout pages to steal payment card data (Magecart groups 2018–2025).
Chinese-speaking threat actor known for exploiting Foxit PDF Reader zero-days (CVE-2023-27325, CVE-2024-26931).
Linux kernel DoS via crafted fragmented IPv6 packets – fixed in 2018 but still found in legacy systems.
Chinese cybersecurity community and bug-bounty platform frequently used by state-sponsored actors for zero-day disclosure.
Memory-only ransomware loader used by LockBit 3.0 affiliates (2023–2025) to evade detection.
Google’s post-Android operating system (Zircon microkernel) with strong security boundaries – first devices shipped 2023–2025.
NSA exploit framework leaked by Shadow Brokers in 2017 (similar to Metasploit but for zero-days).
Author of Nmap and founder of the Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) – one of the most respected figures in offensive security.
Critical unauthenticated remote code execution in F5 BIG-IP management interface exploited by multiple APTs and ransomware groups within hours of disclosure in May 2022 (CVSS 9.8).
2020 authentication bypass and remote code execution in BIG-IP Traffic Management User Interface (TMUI) used in widespread attacks against government and financial targets.
Ongoing phishing-as-a-service operations using AiTM (Adversary-in-the-Middle) frameworks like EvilProxy and Evilginx3 to bypass MFA on Meta/Facebook accounts.
Lightweight PowerShell-based post-exploitation framework developed by Russian-speaking actors (2024–2025) as a Cobalt Strike alternative.

One of the most successful social-engineering lures since 2018 (SocGholish/FakeUpdates). Victims are shown fake Chrome/Firefox/Flash update pop-ups that drop NetSupport RAT, Cobalt Strike, or ransomware.
Registration of domains that are visually similar to legitimate ones (typosquatting, homographs, combo-squatting). Example: g00gle[.]com, microsoft-login[.]net.
Law-enforcement impersonation technique used by extortion gangs and harassment groups to obtain victim data from tech companies via forged court orders (exposed by KrebsOnSecurity 2023–2025).
CrowdStrike’s fully managed detection and response (MDR) service that includes 24/7 hunting, remediation, and concierge support.
Russian GRU-linked threat actor active since 2007, responsible for DNC hack (2016), German Bundestag (2015), WADA (2016), and countless zero-day deployments.
Iranian APT34 (OilRig) custom backdoor family discovered 2023–2025 targeting Middle East energy and government sectors.
Point-of-sale malware family (2016–2022) known for extreme speed in memory scraping and exfiltration of payment card data.
Privilege-escalation technique that exploits overly permissive “Manage This Account” or “Add Workstation” rights in Active Directory (common in healthcare and education).
U.S. federal PKI interoperability framework that cross-certifies government and commercial CAs for secure cross-domain communication.
Windows Embedded feature that redirects disk writes to RAM – abused by attackers to hide malware on kiosks and POS systems.

term: Fileless Persistence via WMI Event Subscription
definition: Technique that creates permanent WMI event filters and consumers to execute payloads without dropping files (common in PowerLurk, Emotet, QakBot).
Highly professional financially motivated group active since 2013, known for sophisticated spear-phishing, POS malware, and ransomware deployment (Ryuk, REvil, BlackMatter).
Bypassing biometric systems using lifted prints, gelatin molds, or 3D-printed replicas. Effectiveness depends on sensor type (capacitive vs optical vs ultrasonic).
Malware that performs its entire malicious action (data exfiltration, ransomware encryption) immediately after execution without establishing C2 or persistence.
Attackers exploit Universal Plug and Play on edge routers to open ports from the inside out, allowing direct inbound connections.
Initial lightweight dropper or downloader whose only job is to fetch and execute the main payload (Emotet Epoch 4/5 loaders, BazarLoader, IcedID).
Process of extracting and analyzing device firmware (routers, IoT, UEFI) to find vulnerabilities or backdoors (binwalk, Ghidra, UEFI Tool).
Software-based Trusted Platform Module implemented in CPU firmware (Intel PTT, AMD fTPM). Vulnerable to physical attacks and some side-channels.
Domain that exhibits suspicious characteristics (newly registered, DGA-like name, no SSL, hosted on bulletproof hosting).
Intelligence alliance comprising Australia, Canada, New Zealand, UK, and USA – known for advanced surveillance capabilities and tool leaks (Vault 7, Snowden).
Persistence technique that modifies Windows system time to trick timestamp-based forensics tools (used by Duqu 2.0 and some APTs).
Leading threat-intelligence company specializing in illicit communities (dark web forums, Telegram channels, carding shops).
Graceful RAT – advanced .NET remote access trojan used by FIN7 since 2020 with full-featured VNC, credential dumping, and process hollowing.
Rowhammer-style attack that flips bits in memory to modify trusted parts of a virtual machine from an untrusted one (2016 research).
Legacy Windows backdoor virus (2008) notable for being one of the first to use NTFS Alternate Data Streams (ADS) for hiding.
See earlier entry – lightweight .NET RAT popular on Russian-speaking forums.
New RaaS group (2024–2025) that uses intermittent encryption (partial files) to speed up encryption while remaining effective.
Command-and-control that leaves no network or disk artifacts (ICMP, DNS TXT records with short TTL, blockchain-based C2).
Attack that tricks a victim into authenticating to a malicious server (NTLM relay, SMB relay, WPAD abuse) to capture hashes.
Security misconfiguration where directories or files are accessible without proper authorization simply by guessing URLs.
Open-source forensic timeline generator used by DFIR teams to correlate events across multiple log sources.
Malware component that hooks browser APIs to steal data entered into web forms before encryption (Zeus, Dridex, Ursnif).
Threat-intelligence division of Fortinet – one of the largest AV signature feeds and zero-day research teams.
Technique used by attackers to hide behind legitimate cloud proxies (Cloudflare, Akamai) while conducting attacks.
Extended intelligence-sharing alliance that includes the Five Eyes plus nine additional countries (SIGINT Seniors Europe).
Microsoft-detected wiper malware deployed by HermeticWizard (Russian GRU) hours before the physical invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.
Legitimate browser proxy extension frequently abused in red-team and criminal operations for traffic tunneling.
POS malware family that scrapes Track 1/Track 2 data directly from process memory using custom memory searching techniques.
Chinese state-sponsored backdoor discovered in 2024 targeting telecommunications providers in Southeast Asia.
Large Android-based botnet (2023–2025) that uses compromised smart TVs and streaming boxes for DDoS and proxy services.
See earlier entry – Modbus/TCP ICS malware used in real-world attacks against Ukrainian critical infrastructure (Dragos 2024).
Complete identity package sold on dark markets (name, DOB, SSN, address, credit card, bank logins, cookies).
Cloud platforms that perform continuous fuzzing on open-source and commercial software (Microsoft OneFuzz, Google OSS-Fuzz).
Informal rule: “Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow” – adapted from Linus’s Law for security vulnerability discovery.

term: GREASE (Generate Random Extensions And Sustain Extensibility)
definition: Mechanism introduced in TLS 1.3 (RFC 8701) that inserts random reserved values in handshake messages to prevent ossification and protocol intolerance by middleboxes. Implemented in Chrome, Firefox, and most modern TLS stacks since 2018.

term: GSMA IoT SAFE (IoT Security Applet For Encryption)
definition: Global standard that uses the SIM/eSIM as a hardware root of trust for storing keys and performing cryptographic operations in IoT devices. Adopted by major telecom operators 2022–2025 (GSMA, ETSI).
One of the oldest still-active IoT/Linux botnet families (2014–2025). Source code leaked early, leading to hundreds of variants used for DDoS and crypto-mining (Mirai’s direct predecessor).
German-UK company that developed and sold FinFisher/FinSpy surveillance software to governments worldwide until exposed by Citizen Lab and multiple leaks 2014–2024.
Apple macOS security feature that enforces code signing and notarization. Bypassed historically via DYLIB hijacking, TCC bypasses, and synthetic clicks (still evolving in macOS Sequoia 15).
AWS service that allows transparent insertion of third-party network virtual appliances (firewalls, IDS/IPS) into VPC traffic flow using GENEVE encapsulation.
Chinese remote access trojan (full name: Gh0st Remote Administration Tool) with source code publicly leaked in 2008. Still used in 2025 by low-sophistication actors and some APTs.
Bypass technique for Intel Processor Trace (PT) that allowed post-exploitation persistence even on fully patched Windows 10 with PatchGuard (CyberArk 2017).
Memory-only malware loader observed in 2024–2025 campaigns that uses AES-encrypted PNG steganography to hide payloads in legitimate-looking images (Elastic Security Labs).
Critical hardware vulnerability in some RISC-V CPU implementations that allows unprivileged code to write arbitrary physical memory (2024, affects several Chinese and open-source cores).
World’s largest code hosting platform. Frequently abused for C2 (GitHub Pages, Actions, Gists), malware hosting, and living-off-the-land attacks (Octopus, KoiBot, 2023–2025 campaigns).
Attack that exploits .git directory exposure on web servers to download full source code repositories (including secrets, keys, and history).
One of the oldest public Certificate Authorities (founded 1996). Issued rogue certificates in 2011 incident and remains a major root in all trust stores.
Kerberos forgery attack using the KRBTGT account hash to mint arbitrary TGTs granting indefinite domain access (Mimikatz “golden_ticket” module, MITRE T1558.001).

Elite vulnerability research team that discloses zero-day bugs after 90 days (or 7 days if in active exploitation). Responsible for discovering Stagefright, Meltdown/Spectre, iMessage BlastDoor bypasses, and hundreds more.
JavaScript-based initial access payload (2020–2025) delivered via compromised WordPress sites and SEO poisoning. Drops GootKit banker or Cobalt Strike.
Modular banking trojan evolved from GootLoader, known for advanced anti-analysis, webinjects, and persistence via scheduled tasks and WMI.
Latin American banking trojan (primarily Brazilian) active since 2017. Uses Delphi, overlays, and Delphi-packed droppers. Resurged in 2024–2025 with MaaS model.
Microsoft’s internal threat detection system (now part of Microsoft 365 Defender) that uses massive-scale time-series analytics across trillions of signals daily.
Software that is not clearly malicious but exhibits undesirable behavior (adware, tracking, cryptominers). Often excluded from traditional AV detection.
China’s offensive DDoS and man-on-the-side injection system first observed in 2015 attacking GitHub (GreatFire.org campaign) and still active in 2025.
Illicit miners that claim to use renewable energy to appear legitimate (common in Nordic countries using hydroelectric power).
Chaos-engineering platform that intentionally injects failures (latency, CPU burn, blackhole) to test system resilience (Netflix Simian Army successor).
Microsoft-revealed technique (2024) that abuses the rarely audited MSC (Microsoft Saved Console) file format for APC-based code execution and EDR evasion.
Active Directory mechanism for centralized configuration management. Frequently abused for persistence (GPO scheduled tasks, logon scripts) and privilege escalation.
Russian cybersecurity and threat-intelligence company known for detailed actor tracking (Silence, MoneyTaker, Cobalt, Lazarus) and the first to report NSO Pegasus in 2016.
AWS-native threat detection service that continuously monitors CloudTrail, VPC Flow Logs, and DNS logs using machine learning and known IOCs.

term: Guideline for Identification of Critical Assets (GICA)
definition: EU NIS2 directive requirement for operators of essential services to map and protect crown-jewel assets.
Heavily obfuscated downloader (formerly CloudEyE) written in auto-generated shellcode-protected Visual Basic. Primary delivery vector for REMCOS, FormBook, and AgentTesla 2021–2025.
Denial-of-service attack using highly compressed files that expand to terabytes when decompressed (also known as zip bomb, common in email gateways).
Open-source project by Google and the OpenSSF to create SBOMs and dependency graphs at scale across the entire software supply chain (2024–2025).
Sequence of pointer offsets (gadgets) in existing code used in Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) attacks to bypass DEP/NX (ROPgadget, ROPemporium).
Peer-to-peer banking trojan and botnet (2011–2014) that used DGA, fast-flux, and encrypted C2. Taken down by Operation Tovar in 2014, later evolved into Dridex.
One of the most successful ransomware-as-a-service platforms (2018–2019). Officially retired in June 2019 after earning developers over $2 billion, then rebranded as REvil/Sodinokibi.
Go-language obfuscator used by many modern Go-based malware families (SparkRAT, GoStealer, Chaos) to defeat static analysis.
Python-based backdoor using Gmail as C2 (draft messages). First seen 2014, still used in low-budget campaigns in 2025.
EU Regulation 2016/679 (effective 2018) that imposes strict rules on personal data processing, breach notification (72 hours), and fines up to 4 % of global turnover.
Dark-web marketplace (2017–2023) that sold “browser fingerprints” (cookies, plugins, fonts, WebGL) for account takeover. Shut down by FBI Operation Cookie Monster in April 2023.
Lightweight Linux distribution used as the base for many C2 redirectors and VPS pivots because of its minimal footprint and easy automation.
Unremovable Google Cloud Platform vulnerability (CVE-2023-32731) that allowed permanent application-level access even after token deletion (discovered by Astrix Security 2023).
Android banking trojan (primarily targeting Southeast Asia) that evolved from screen-recording malware into full on-device fraud using Accessibility Services (2023–2025).
Legacy Windows technique that replaces msgina.dll or custom GINA to intercept logon credentials (pre-Windows Vista, still works on XP/2003).

term: Global Ransomware Attack Surface Mapping Project
definition: CrowdStrike-led initiative (2023–2025) that continuously scans the Internet for exposed RDP, SMB, and VPN endpoints to measure ransomware risk.
Massive increase in malware written in Go (GoLang) since 2021 due to cross-compilation, static linking, and built-in obfuscation (Kinsing, XMRig, Chaos, Prometei).
Forge SAML responses using stolen Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) signing keys to impersonate any user in cloud environments (Azure AD/Entra ID, Okta).
Advanced search operator techniques to find exposed sensitive data, vulnerable systems, or misconfigurations (site:, inurl:, filetype:, intitle: – GHDB by Offensive Security).
Technique where legitimate but compromised websites are manipulated to rank highly for business-related searches (“contract template”, “NDA pdf”) and deliver Gootloader.
Massive credential-theft campaigns that combine infostealers (RedLine, Raccoon, Vidar) with underground marketplaces and Telegram bots.
Using graph databases (Neo4j, BloodHound, Azure AD) to map relationships between users, computers, groups, and permissions for attack path analysis.
Commercial iPhone unlocking tool by Grayshift used by law enforcement. Supports iOS 11–17 with partial and full filesystem extraction (bypasses USB Restricted Mode).
Iranian APT34 (OilRig) custom backdoor family discovered 2024–2025 targeting Middle East telecom and government entities.
Android trojan campaign (2021–2024) that infected >10 million devices via fake premium SMS subscriptions through malicious Google Play apps.
Lightweight Android RAT sold on Russian forums since 2022, known for real-time screen sharing, SMS interception, and call recording.
Historical vulnerability (MS14-025) where SYSVOL stored cpassword-encrypted passwords that were actually reversible using a public Microsoft key (2008–2014).
Buffer overflow in GRUB2 bootloader that allowed bypassing Secure Boot on most Linux systems (2020). Fixed by BootHole patches and revocation of affected keys.
DevSecOps platform that integrates SAST, SCA, secret scanning, and IaC security directly into GitHub/GitLab workflows.
Highly obfuscated variant of Guloader that uses multiple layers of AutoIt, NSIS, and shellcode to deliver AgentTesla or REMCOS.
Iranian state-sponsored backdoor used in 2024–2025 attacks against Israeli critical infrastructure (ClearSky Cyber Security).
Chinese-speaking initial access broker (IAB) active 2023–2025, specializing in exploiting Confluence, Citrix, and Zimbra zero-days for ransomware affiliates.
Malware family that uses gzip-compressed payloads hidden in legitimate-looking Windows event logs for persistence and evasion.
Early (2014) APT-grade memory-only implant capable of running entirely in RAM and surviving reboots via reflective DLL injection.
Google’s internal name for its Titan M2/Titan 2 security chip used in Pixel 8+ devices with strong verified boot and keystore isolation.

Microsoft-named Chinese state-sponsored group that exploited four zero-day vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange Server (ProxyLogon chain CVE-2021-26855, 26857, 26858, 27065) in early 2021, compromising >250,000 servers worldwide within hours of disclosure.
Russian ICS-targeted malware (2013–2014, still active) that infected legitimate energy software installers via supply-chain compromise and used OPC scanning to map SCADA networks (ICS-CERT, Dragos).
Anonymous hack that exposed emails showing the company planned fake personas, disinformation campaigns, and zero-day sales to the U.S. government, severely damaging the industry’s reputation.
Physical attack vector demonstrated by Red Balloon Security (2020–2024) that reprograms HDMI chip firmware to create a malicious input device (keyboard injection, video overlay, data exfiltration).
2016 attack that exploited TLS compression side-channels (CRIME successor) using HTTP/2 and browser features to steal data (still mitigated by disabling compression).

U.S. regulation (45 CFR Part 160 and 164) that requires covered entities and business associates to implement administrative, physical, and technical safeguards for electronic protected health information (ePHI).
APT29 (Cozy Bear) custom backdoor discovered by Mandiant in 2024–2025 diplomatic targeting campaigns using OneDrive and Dropbox for C2.

Deprecated header (RFC 7469) that instructed browsers to only accept specific CA certificates for a domain. Removed from browsers in 2018–2021 due to risk of self-inflicted DoS (replaced by Certificate Transparency + Expect-CT).

Proactive security team that assumes breach and continuously searches for indicators of compromise using hypotheses, big data analytics, and behavioral detection (CrowdStrike OverWatch, Microsoft DART).

Windows 10/11 virtualization-based security feature (also called Memory Integrity) that runs code-integrity checks inside the secure kernel, blocking unsigned drivers and kernel exploits (required for Windows 11).
Leading bug-bounty and disclosure platform that has paid out over $300 million to researchers since 2012. Used by Google, Microsoft, DoD VDP, and hundreds of organizations.
Techniques used after ProxyLogon: web-shell deployment (China Chopper variants), credential dumping via ProcDump on LSASS, and creation of new domain accounts with RDP rights.
Long-running downloader (2014–2025) primarily used to deliver Cobalt Strike, FickerStealer, and ransomware. Known for malicious Word/Excel documents with heavy macro obfuscation.
Immutable, air-gapped, or WORM (Write-Once-Read-Many) backup storage designed to resist ransomware deletion/modification (Veeam Hardened Repository, Rubrik, Cohesity).

Tamper-resistant hardware device that generates, stores, and manages cryptographic keys. Required for high-assurance PKI, payment processing (PCI HSM), and cloud KMS (AWS CloudHSM, Azure Dedicated HSM).
World’s fastest open-source password recovery tool supporting hundreds of hash types, GPU/CPU clusters, and mask/brute-force/hybrid attacks.
Elastic Security’s threat-hunting query language and repository of pre-built detection rules mapped to MITRE ATT&CK.
HTTP request/response smuggling using folded headers, chunked encoding mismatches, or ambiguous parsing (H2C smuggling, James Kettle research).
U.S. HHS division that shares threat intelligence and best practices specifically for healthcare (ransomware warnings, ALPHV/BlackCat TTPs).
Critical OpenSSL bug (2014) that leaked server private keys, session cookies, and passwords from memory due to missing bounds checking in TLS heartbeat extension. Affected ~17 % of HTTPS servers.
Linux memory-only backdoor framework used by Chinese APT41 in 2024–2025 attacks against Southeast Asian telecom providers (CrowdStrike).
Cryptanalytic technique used in rainbow table attacks to crack hashes faster than brute force (still relevant for LM/NTLM, MD5).
Ransomware family first seen in 2017, later used by North Korean Lazarus Group in targeted attacks (Ryuk’s predecessor).
Destructive wiper deployed against Ukrainian organizations on 23 February 2022 (hours before Russian invasion) using valid digital signatures from Hermetica Digital Ltd.
Iranian APT33 (Elfin) subgroup focused on destructive attacks against Middle East energy and aviation sectors (Shamoon 3, ZeroCleare).
U.S. government name for North Korean state-sponsored actors (Lazarus Group, Bluenoroff, Andariel).
Chinese Linux rootkit and backdoor toolkit discovered in 2019 targeting telecom and financial institutions (fully undetectable at the time).
Individual or system critical to an adversary’s objectives (C-level executives, domain admins, payment systems, OT engineers).
MITRE ATT&CK technique (T1574) covering DLL search-order hijacking, PATH interception, AppInit_DLLs, and Winlogon helper DLLs.
Russian-speaking ransomware affiliate group that exploited Log4Shell and ProxyShell extensively in 2021–2023 before Hive RaaS was dismantled.
RaaS platform (2021–2023) taken down by FBI in January 2023 via infiltration. Known for Rust-based encryptor and aggressive double-extortion tactics.
Deliberately vulnerable or monitored user account seeded in Active Directory to detect lateral movement and credential access.
Decoy system or service designed to attract, detect, and analyze attacker behavior (Kippo, Cowrie, Dionaea, OpenCanary).
Chinese nationalist hacker group active since the early 2000s, known for defacements and DDoS during geopolitical events.
Technique that intercepts function calls or events (API hooking, inline hooking, IAT patching) used by both EDR and malware (User-mode and kernel-mode hooks).
Encryption that is terminated and re-encrypted at each network hop (vs end-to-end). Common in VPNs and some TLS termination proxies.
Agent that monitors system logs, file integrity, registry changes, and process behavior (OSSEC, Wazuh, Tripwire).
Attack that manipulates the Host header to bypass validation, cause cache poisoning, or trigger password-reset poisoning.
Lightweight red-team C2 framework written in Rust with focus on memory-only execution and EDR evasion (2024–2025).
Popular VPN service repeatedly caught in privacy scandals (2016–2018) for injecting ads and tracking users.
Go-based credential stealer used by Scattered Spider (UNC3944) in 2024–2025 MGM/Caesars casino attacks.
Multi-stage compromise where each layer relies on the previous one failing silently (common in supply-chain and island-hopping attacks).
Russian-speaking initial access broker that sells RDP and VPN access to ransomware groups (2023–2025).
Managed EDR and security platform targeted at MSPs and SMBs with strong 24/7 human-led threat hunting.
Trojan used in Operation Aurora (2009–2010) – Chinese attack against Google, Adobe, and dozens of tech/defense companies that led to creation of Microsoft MAPP and Google’s exit from China.
Danish state-sponsored campaign (2024–2025) using custom implants against Russian and Belarusian targets (rare Western offensive operation made public).
Russian in-memory loader used by Turla (Venomous Bear) since 2018, capable of running .NET and PowerShell payloads without touching disk.
Security technique that monitors virtual machines from the hypervisor level (outside the guest OS) to detect rootkits and advanced malware (VMware Carbon Black, Microsoft Defender for Cloud).
Rootkit that operates at Ring -1 (below the OS kernel) using Intel VT-x or AMD-V (Blue Pill, SubVirt – theoretical but demonstrated in labs).
QUIC-based proxy tool heavily used by Chinese actors for C2 and exfiltration because of its speed and censorship-resistance properties.
Platform-hosted or scoped disclosure programs that allow ethical hackers to report vulnerabilities without legal risk. DoD, EU, and most Fortune 500 now run VDPs.
China Chopper variants and custom ASPX shells dropped during the 2021 Exchange attacks (e.g., /owa/auth/supData.aspx, /ecp/js/legit.js) that persisted for years on unpatched servers.
One of the longest-running malspam operations (2014–2025) using thread-hijacked emails, password-protected ZIPs, and malicious Excel 4.0 macros.
Newer ransomware (2023–2025) that negotiates aggressively and offers “discounts” for fast payment. Uses partial encryption for speed.
Android and iOS feature that stores private keys in a secure element or Titan/SEP chip, making extraction extremely difficult (StrongBox Keymaster, Secure Enclave).
Technique that copies password hashes from one system to another for pass-the-hash attacks (especially NTLM in Windows environments).
Secrets-management system widely used in DevOps. Multiple critical vulnerabilities 2021–2024 allowed unauthenticated RCE and credential leakage.
Ultra-fast open-source Windows event-log (evtx) analysis tool written in Rust. Used by DFIR teams for threat hunting across thousands of endpoints.
Linux rootkit and backdoor used by Chinese APT41 in 2024–2025 attacks against Southeast Asian government and telecom targets.
Formerly Splunk Enterprise Security – the world’s most widely deployed SIEM with advanced analytics, UEBA, and SOAR integration.
Worm component of the February 2022 Ukrainian wiper attacks that spread HermeticWiper via SMB and WMI (Russian GRU).
Free tool that enumerates every possible persistence location on Windows (more comprehensive than Autoruns in some cases).
Open-source ransomware project (2015) that was forked into dozens of real-world strains (EDA2, Stampado, etc.).
Full operating system that allows attackers to fully interact and pivot (vs low-interaction which only emulates services).
Technique that places malicious DLLs in directories searched before legitimate ones (C:\Windows\System32, application directories).
Windows privilege-escalation vulnerability that exposed SAM, SECURITY, and SYSTEM hives due to overly permissive shadow-copy permissions.
Any fake credential, API key, database record, or file designed to trigger an alert when used (Thinkst Canarytokens, Microsoft AAD honeytokens).
Component used by both EDR and malware to intercept API calls (Microsoft Detours, EasyHook, mhook).
Red-team technique that combines multiple persistence mechanisms in a single payload (registry, scheduled task, service, WMI subscription).
Security response action that quarantines an infected endpoint from the network while preserving forensic evidence (CrowdStrike, Carbon Black, Defender).
Microsoft technology (Windows Server 2022+) that applies security updates without rebooting the OS (in-memory patching).
Abuse of .hta files (HTML + scripting) that run with full user privileges and bypass most application control solutions.
HTTP Request Smuggling (CL.TE, TE.CL) that exploits front-end/back-end parser differences to poison caches, bypass auth, or perform XSS (James Kettle, PortSwigger).
David Bianco’s pyramid model (0–5) that measures an organization’s proactive threat-hunting capability.
Classic password brute-forcing tool supporting 50+ protocols (SSH, RDP, SMB, HTTP, etc.). Still used in 2025.
See earlier entry – enforces kernel code signing inside the secure VTL-1 world.
Next-generation QUIC/UDP tunneling proxy with built-in obfuscation, widely used by both attackers and censorship-evaders in China and Iran.

Specialized cyber-criminal role that gains and sells initial footholds (RDP, VPN, Citrix, web shells) to ransomware affiliates and other groups. Top IABs in 2024–2025 earn millions per year (Mandiant, Group-IB, Intel471).

Technique that encapsulates data inside ICMP echo request/reply packets to bypass firewalls and exfiltrate data or establish C2 (icmpsh, Scapy, Loki). Still effective on poorly configured networks (MITRE T1095).

General term for SCADA, DCS, PLCs, RTUs, HMIs, and safety systems used in critical infrastructure (power, water, oil & gas, manufacturing). Primary target of nation-state actors (Dragos, CISA ICS-CERT).
OWASP Top 10 vulnerability where an attacker can access objects (users, files, tickets) by manipulating identifiers (user_id=123 → user_id=124) due to missing authorization checks.
Combined network or host-based system that detects and can automatically block malicious activity (Snort, Suricata, Palo Alto NGFW, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint).
Multiple in-the-wild zero-days in Internet Explorer 11 (CVE-2023-29324, CVE-2023-32014) used by North Korean and Chinese actors even after Microsoft declared IE end-of-life.
Self-propagating malware that spreads laterally across IoT devices (Mirai, Reaper, Satori, VPNFilter, Echobot). Still the dominant threat to routers, cameras, and smart devices.
Decentralized peer-to-peer file storage network increasingly abused for permanent malware hosting, phishing kits, and ransomware leak sites because content is unremovable once pinned.
International standard for information security management systems (ISMS). The most widely recognized certifiable framework (requires risk assessment, SoA, and continuous improvement).
Modern SOC process that tracks and remediates all known initial access vectors (exposed RDP/VPN, phishing domains, vulnerable public apps) in real time (Microsoft Defender XDR, Palo Alto Cortex).
Highly sophisticated banking trojan turned loader-as-a-service (2017–2025). Uses advanced anti-analysis (VM detection, process hollowing) and delivers Cobalt Strike, TrickBot, or ransomware.
Service that performs authentication and issues identity tokens (Okta, Azure AD/Entra ID, Ping Identity, Auth0). Compromise of an IdP gives attackers access to all federated applications.
Cyber workforce training and readiness platform that uses gamified labs and real-world simulations to measure and improve blue/red/purple team skills.
Python library and collection of tools (wmiexec, psexec, smbexec, secretsdump) used by both pentesters and real attackers for lateral movement and credential access.
Leading WAF and DDoS protection vendor known for Incapsula CDN and advanced bot mitigation using device fingerprinting and behavioral analysis.
Technique that runs malicious code entirely in RAM without touching disk (PowerShell -WindowStyle Hidden, reflective DLL injection, .NET Assembly.Load) to evade AV/EDR.
Broader term for LFI/RFI, XXE, path traversal, and any vulnerability that forces a system to include attacker-controlled resources.
The most sophisticated ICS malware ever publicly analyzed (2016 Sandworm attack on Ukrainian grid). Capable of directly manipulating IEC 104, OLE for Process Control, and circuit breakers.
Scanning and hardening Terraform, CloudFormation, Ansible, and Pulumi templates for misconfigurations (Checkov, tfsec, Bridgecrew, Prisma Cloud IaC Scan).
MITRE ATT&CK tactic (TA0001) covering phishing, valid accounts, external remote services, supply-chain compromise, and drive-by compromise.
OWASP Top 10 A03:2021 category that includes SQLi, NoSQLi, command injection, LDAP injection, XPath injection, and SSRF.
Malicious or negligent actions by employees, contractors, or partners. The hardest threat to detect and prevent (CERT Insider Threat Center, Dtex, Forcepoint).
Cryptographic verification that data or code has not been tampered with (file hashes, code signing, IMA/EVM on Linux, Windows WHQL signing).
Separate microcontroller in all Intel CPUs since 2008 with full system access even when powered off. Multiple critical vulnerabilities (Silent Bob, SA-00086, INTEL-SA-00213).
Red-team exercise that mimics real-world APT or ransomware attack with full adversary emulation (Mandiant Red Team, CrowdStrike Adversary Emulation, SCYTHE).
SANS-operated volunteer early-warning system that collects and analyzes firewall logs from thousands of organizations worldwide (dshield.org).
Lockheed Martin model (recon → weaponize → deliver → exploit → install → C2 → actions) that predates MITRE ATT&CK but is still used in many SOCs.
Advanced business email compromise where attackers hijack real vendor email accounts and modify payment instructions mid-conversation (FBI IC3 2024–2025 reports).
Forensic artifact (hash, IP, domain, registry key, file path) that indicates a system has been compromised. Often over-relied upon vs behavioral detection.
Firmware analysis tools (Binwalk, Firmadyne, FACT) that extract, emulate, and scan IoT/embedded device images for vulnerabilities and backdoors.
Chinese state-sponsored group active since 2010 known for custom tools (SysUpdate, PlugX variants) and long-term espionage against aerospace and telecom.
Attack technique where adversaries compromise one organization to pivot to its partners, customers, or suppliers (SolarWinds, Kaseya, Accellion, Target HVAC vendor breach).
Machine-learning anomaly detection algorithm widely used in UEBA and fraud detection systems (Microsoft Defender, Splunk UBA, Exabeam).
Multiple critical vulnerabilities (CVE-2023-46805, CVE-2024-21887, CVE-2024-21893) in Ivanti Pulse Secure VPN exploited by Chinese actors (UNC5221) against governments worldwide.
Formerly Pulse Secure – enterprise VPN and NAC solution repeatedly targeted by nation-states due to widespread deployment in critical sectors.
2023–2025 evolution of IcedID that hides malicious DLLs inside legitimate-looking PNG/JPG images using steganography, then extracts and reflectively loads them at runtime (Elastic, Microsoft).
Emerging Gartner category (2023–2025) that combines identity governance, privileged access management, and real-time detection of identity-based attacks (Silverfort, BeyondTrust, Semperis).
Chinese APT41 campaign (2024–2025) that uses Google Drive and Dropbox as dead-drop resolvers and for stealthy C2 (CrowdStrike).
Use of Impacket tools (psexec.py, wmiexec.py, smbexec.py, dcomexec.py) for password-less lateral movement using stolen NTLM hashes or tickets.
OWASP Top 10 A08:2021 vulnerability where untrusted data is used to instantiate objects, leading to RCE (Java SerialKiller, .NET ysoserial, PHP Gadget Chains).
Linux kernel feature that cryptographically measures and attests all files executed or opened, preventing unauthorized modifications (used in hardened distros and TPM remote attestation).
Continuous or on-demand scanning of the entire IPv4 (or IPv6) space for vulnerable services (Shodan, Censys, ZoomEye, BinaryEdge, Project Sonar).

Network security appliance that can actively block malicious traffic in-line (vs IDS which only alerts). Modern IPS uses signatures, behavioral analysis, and ML (Palo Alto, Cisco Secure IPS, TippingPoint).
The #1 ransomware and banking-trojan delivery method in 2024–2025: fake invoices in PDF, XLS, DOC, or OneNote with embedded macros, links, or LNK files.
2017–2018 botnet that improved on Mirai by exploiting known vulnerabilities instead of just default passwords (affected >1 million organizations).
Behavioral analytics cybersecurity company founded by ex-NSA director Keith Alexander. Known for collective defense and network detection using “IronDome” shared intelligence.
Secure browsing solution that runs web sessions in disposable containers or remote cloud browsers (Ericom, Menlo Security, Talon Cyber, Cloudflare Browser Isolation).
Granular security policy that addresses a single risk or technology (acceptable-use, mobile-device, cloud-usage) as required by ISO 27001 and NIST 800-53.
2023 zero-days in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (formerly MobileIron) chained for unauthenticated RCE, exploited by Chinese APT5 against Norwegian government.
Apple’s iMessage sandboxing service introduced in iOS 14 to prevent zero-click exploits. Partially bypassed in 2021–2024 by FORCEDENTRY (NSO Pegasus) and other state-level exploits.
2024 zero-click Wi-Fi daemon exploit chain used by state actors that granted full device compromise without user interaction (Citizen Lab).
iOS 17+ feature that cryptographically verifies you are messaging the intended person and detects man-in-the-middle attempts (especially on iCloud+ with Advanced Data Protection).

Active TLS fingerprinting tool and hash that identifies server TLS configuration (cipher suites, extensions, order, ALPN, version) with high accuracy. Used by defenders and attackers to detect Cobalt Strike, malicious scanners, and anomalous servers (Salesforce research 2020–2025).

Client and server TLS fingerprinting hashes created from the ClientHello/ServerHello fields (cipher suites, extensions, elliptic curves). Integrated into Zeek, Suricata, CrowdStrike, Microsoft Defender, and most NDR platforms to detect malware C2 (John Althouse, Salesforce).

Advanced adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) phishing framework that uses Node.js reverse proxies to steal credentials and session tokens even when MFA is present. Successor to Evilginx2 and heavily used in 2024–2025 BEC campaigns.

Ransomware tactic where attackers demand extremely high payments (tens or hundreds of millions) from very large enterprises, knowing they can afford it (e.g., UnitedHealth/Change Healthcare 2024 $22M payment).
Apple-focused endpoint security and compliance solution that provides behavioral analytics, malware prevention, and threat hunting specifically for macOS, iOS, and iPadOS fleets.

Exploitation of insecure Java object deserialization (ObjectInputStream) using gadget chains (ysoserial, Commons Collections, Spring) leading to remote code execution. Still common in 2025 despite JDK mitigations.
Techniques such as variable renaming, string encryption, control-flow flattening, and domain generation used by malware (Emotet, GootLoader, SocGholish) to evade static detection.
